I did not see him lay hold of any one. Some person kicked my arm to prevent my picking it up.

ROBERT BOWSER
. I am a constable. I was at the fire. Glassborough gave the prisoner to me; I took him to the watch-house. He said nothing to it.
MR. WAKELEY re-examined. Nobody but me laid hold of the man till the constable did. I did not part with him till the constable took him from me, It was between two and three o'clock in the morning.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of it.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1091.
CHARLOTTE HENSHAW
and
SARAH HIPPENSTALL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , one hat, value 8 s; one coat, value 16 s.; one waistcoat, value 8 s., and one handkerchief, value 4 s , the goods of
Francis Lillicrap
.

FRANCIS LILLICRAP
. I am a wheelwright . On the 13th of September I came from Plymouth, and about seven o'clock in the evening I saw the prisoners at the Cooper's Arms, Stretton-ground. I enquired for a lodging, and they took me to theirs in Duck-lane
- I did not expect them to stop with me. I paid them 3 s. for the
room, and gave them money to drink. I awoke about eleven o'clock, and missed my clothes. They were apprehended that night.

ROBERT HUDSON
. I am a watchman. About eleven o'clock I heard a cry of Watch! and found the prosecutor with only his trowsers on. He said two girls had robbed him, but he did not know they were women of the town - it is a very bad house. About half-past twelve o'clock I saw the prisoners sitting on a step; they said it was no use to take a candle up till they were certain he was gone. We afterwards took them both in the room.
JAMES M'CULLOUGH. I am a watchman. I was present, and took the prisoners; they were bad girls - nobody could mistake them. There is a hole by the door to unbolt it outside.
HENSHAW'S Defence. We took him home, but did not rob him.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1092.
JAMES WESTWOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 2 ounces of silver, value 4 s. , the goods of
Thomas Emmett
.

THOMAS EMMETT
. I am a working silversmith , and live in Sutton-street, Clerkenwell
; the prisoner had worked for me, and I gave him leave to work in my shop. We missed silver several times, and on the 28th of July, when he left, he was brought back; I charged him with taking silver, and desired him to produce it - he produced some from his pocket.

CHARLES GREEN
. I followed the prisoner and brought him back. He denied having any silver, and afterwards produced it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was intoxicated, and found it in my pocket, but do not know how it came there.
GUILTY . Aged 52.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1093.
JONATHAN HASLOP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of August , two shirts, value 7 s.; one shift, value 2 s.; one shawl, value 2 s.; two pair of stockings, value 1 s., and one apron, value 9 d. , the goods of
Owen Hagan
.

SUSAN HAGAN
. I am the wife of
Owen Hagan
, we live in Turk's-row, Chelsea
. On the 2d of August, at two o'clock in the afternoon, these things were safe on the first floor, I went into another room, and when I came out they were gone. I went down stairs and mentioned it, and about three o'clock I found the prisoner in custody with them at the Cheshire Cheese, public-house; he said he did not take them himself.

SARAH FISHER
. I keep the house. I saw the prisoner standing at the corner of the passage for ten minutes, but did not see him go in or out; he was the only person near the house. I afterwards saw him going down the road.

MARY SNELLGROVE
. I was sitting on the steps of the Mermaid, next yard to the prosecutrix's, and saw the prisoner pass without anything. He returned in about half an hour, with a blue and white spotted bundle under his arm, going towards the Cheshire Cheese; I asked him what he would take for his bundle? he made no answer. I told the prosecutrix, and directed her which way he went. He returned in two or three minutes, and said
"Who is that that has lost her bundle?" I said,
"A poor woman."

SARAH FOSTER
. I live in Jew's-row. I saw the prisoner come down with a blue and white spotted bundle, and saw him apprehended.

WILLIAM KING
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner in charge at the Cheshire Cheese with the bundle - he said he did not leave it there. I found three skeleton keys on him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The landlady said I did not leave them there.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1094.
JOHN WEST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 20 lbs. of lead, value 2 s., the goods of
Joseph Goddard
, and fixed to his dwelling-house .

MR.
JOSEPH GODDARD
. I live at No. 14, Southampton-street, Bloomsbury
. On the 11th of July the lead pipe was stolen from my front area.

GEORGE HEATH. I am a watchman. After calling three o'clock I was passing Mr. Goddard's area, and saw something black over the cistern - I found it was the prisoner; I secured and took him to the watch-house. I found the lead pipe broken in three pieces, and doubled up in the area, it weighed 24 lbs. I heard something fall from him in the area.

MICHAEL SCHRINE
. I assisted in securing the prisoner in the area, and found the lead.
Prisoner's Defence. Some drunken gentlemen knocked my hat over the rails, and I went for it.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1095.
JOHN BRIANT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 18 yards of printed calico, value 10 s. , the goods of
Thomas James Love
.

THOMAS JAMES LOVE
. I am a linen-draper , and live at Shadwell
. On the 19th of August this calico hung at the door inside the shop. Shade alarmed me, I ran out, and saw the prisoner thirty yards off, with another man. He called out to the other man
"Go it, Jack!" I took him in charge.

HENRY SHADE
. I am a cabinet-maker, and live at Ratcliff-highway. I was coming from a public-house, about eleven o'clock at night, nearly opposite Love's, and saw the prisoner and another man standing on his steps. I saw the prisoner cut something and put it on his arm, it appeared to be dark cloth - I informed Love, and we pursued them. The prisoner cried out to his companion,
"Go it, Jack!" I supposed he had the calico.
Prisoner's Defence. The gentleman said he would take me whether I was the man or not.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1096.
STEPHEN JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , three spoons, value 10 s. , the goods of
William James Davies
.

JOHN TURNER
. I am a basket-maker, and live in Coventry-court, Haymarket, and work in Rupert-street. On the 14th of August, about half-past five o'clock, Bailey and I were walking together, heard the cry of Stop thief! turned round, and saw the prisoners running in the road from the cry in Rupert-street. I tried to catch hold of the prisoner, but missed, and Bailey stopped him - he immediately dropped two spoons.

RICHARD BAILEY
. I stopped the prisoner, and picked up the spoons which he dropped.

HUGH CHURCHILL
. I am a watchman. I saw the prisoner and another man at the corner of Macclesfield-street, the other was fishing down the prosecutor's area, and hooked some spoons up the window. They saw me, and ran away. I followed, crying Stop thief, till the prisoner was secured, he threw three spoons down; I picked one up, and Bailey two.

JOHN HOULDRICK
. I found a hook and part of a rod, on the prisoner.

WILLIAM JAMES DAVIS
. I live in Macclesfield-street
. The spoons are mine.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1197.
PHOEBE PAGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , one sheet, value 2 s., and two blankets, value 4 s., the goods of
William Moss
, in a lodging-room .

MARY MOSS
. I am the wife of
William Moss
, and live in Wheeler's-alley, Spitalfields
. On the 11th of July, the prisoner took my front-room furnished and on the 23d I saw her go out with a bundle, and said I suspected it was my things. She said if I thought all was not right, to go and look. I went up, found her husband on the bed, and missed two blankets and a sheet.

HARRIET TAPLEY
. I bought a sheet of the prisoner for 18 d.

WILLIAM LUCKFOLD
. I took her into custody. She said I should find the blankets in Long-alley. I did so.
(Property produced, and sworn to.)
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1098.
JOHN ELY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of July , one gown, value 3 s., and one box, value 2 s. , the goods of
Thomas Parrish
.

THOMAS PARRISH
. I live in Davis-place, Chelsea
. On the 22d of July, about five o'clock in the morning, I found the prisoner in my room with his shoes off. He was quite a stranger. I collared him, and found my box and gown moved to the door.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I took it for a public-house.
GUILTY . Aged 42.

Confined Six Months , and
Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1099.
RICHARD THORETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , one jacket, value 3 s.; one pair of of trowsers, value 3 s.; one shawl, value 1 s.; one pair of stockings, value 6 d., and one cake of soap, value 18 d. , the goods of
John Burgess
.

JOHN BURGESS
. I live at Colebrook
. On the 2d of August I expected a parcel from Mr. Biddlecome, it did not arrive. I found the prisoner at Eaton that day, with the jacket and trowsers on him. I saw him give a woman a pair of stockings before I got up to him.

THOMAS LEXTON
. I am a constable of Stanmore. The prisoner was given into my charge, for stealing the bundle, he said voluntarily that he committed the robbery, but it was the first he ever did, and if he got through it, it would be a warning to him, and that the soap and shawl were hid in Ditton Park.

GEORGE BIDDLECOMBE
. I am steward of the Naval Institution. I sent a parcel containing these things to the Old White Horse Cellar, directed to Burgess. I had given them to him.

JOHN LAMBERT
. I am a waggoner. I had one parcel, and missed it at Colebrook. The prisoner went down in the waggon that day.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was in distress.
GUILTY . Aged 43.
Confined Two Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before H. R. Reynolds, Esq.

1100.
ANN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of June , forty-eight handkerchiefs, value 5 l, , the goods of
Charles Dimes
.

CHARLES DIMES
. I am a haberdasher , and live in Holborn. On the 8th of June, the prisoner came to my shop, and said she was servant to the niece of Mrs. Collyer, of the Bull Inn, who was married, and lived in Northampton-square, and her mistress wished to see some handkerchiefs, that she was going out, and they must be sent directly. I looked out three or four dozen, and sent my daughter with them. They then went away together.

ELIZA DIMES
. My father sent me with the prisoner. I had the parcel. When we got to the back of Merlin's Cave, public-house
, she said

"This is our house, if you will stop a few minutes in the garden I will see if my master is at home." She spoke to a person at the bar, returned and said she did not know what to do, for her mistress was gone to her sister's. I agreed to go there. She said I could wait in the parlour till she returned. I gave them to her and sat down in Merlin's Cave. She did not return, and was apprehended two days afterwards. I gave them to her to shew her mistress, she was to bring me back what her mistress did not choose.

JOHN BARNLEY
. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner, and found two duplicates in her pocket, and three more in a bureau in her room.

ALEXANDER MILNE
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 9th of June, the prisoner pledged three handkerchiefs, and on the 10th two more.

JOHN WHELDEN
. On the 8th of June, the prisoner pledged eight handkerchiefs with me.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was sent by Mr. Patterson for them, and gave them to him. He said he should send back what he did not keep.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury before H. R. Reynolds, Esq.

1101.
ANN DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , two gowns. value 4 s.; one shawl, value 12 s.; two handkerchiefs, value 6 s,; one spencer, value 4 s.; one pair of salt-holders, value 2 s.; two castors, value 2 s. , the goods of
Eliza Pounder
.

ELIZA POUNDER
. I live in Litchfield-street, Soho
. On the 5th of August, the prisoner came to lodge with me. I missed this property, and gave her in charge.

ROBERT HILDITCH
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 9th of August the prisoner pawned a shawl for 10 s., and on the 12th a gown for 4 s.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before H. R. Reynolds, Esq.

1102.
GEORGE OLDHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , one handkerchief, value 2 s., the goods of
John Stephens
, from his person .

JOHN STEPHENS
. I am a merchant , and live in the Adelphi. On the 9th of July, about ten o'clock at night, I was coming along the Strand
, felt something touch my pocket, looked round, and caught hold of the prisoner, who was immediately behind me, and took a handkerchief from his waistcoat, which was not mine. A person came up, and said, in his hearing, that he saw the prisoner give my handkerchief to another. I gave him in charge.

THOMAS GROVES
. I am a sword-cutler. I was going down the Strand, and saw the prisoner in company with another. I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from the prosecutor's coat-pocket, and give it to one of the others, who ran across the street. The prosecutor turned round, and I secured him. I saw it distinctly.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years . - Recommended to Mercy.
Third Middlesex Jury, before H. R. Reynolds, Esq.

1103.
THOMAS EVANS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , one handkerchief, value 2 s., the goods of
John Stephens
, from his person .

JOHN STEPHENS
. On the 3d of July I was again coming up the Strand
, and near Bedford-street, felt a touch at my pocket; turned round, saw four boys behind me, and saw the prisoner, who was one of them, drop my handkerchief. I secured him, and the others dispersed.
GUILTY . Aged 13.

Transported for Seven Years -
Penitentiary
.
Third Middlesex Jury, before H. R. Reynolds, Esq.

1104.
JOSEPH COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , one watch, value 25 l.; two seals, value 9 l.; one key, value 1 l., and one ring, value 1 l., the goods of
Samuel Verdy Read
, from his person .

SAMUEL VERDY READ
. I am a ship-owner in Jamaica . On the 21st of July, about nine o'clock in the evening, I was going by George-yard
, with a lady on my left arm. The prisoner made a slip with his foot, and fell slightly with his head against my breast, at that instant he made a snatch at my watch, pulled it out, and ran up George-yard with it. I immediately called Stop thief! and received several violent blows from others. An officer knocked him down, and the case of the watch dropped from him immediately. I saw it fall from him. I never lost sight of him till he was secured.

SAMUEL MILLER
. I am an officer. I was in George-yard, heard the cry of Stop thief! and stopped the prisoner who was running before all the rest, we both fell down, and at this instant the case fell on the ground, and the watch close to it. It fell from him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before H. R. Reynolds, Esq.

1105.
ROBERT BAKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , two seals, value 6 s., and one ring, value 1 s., the goods of
John Thomas Woodham
, from his person .

JOHN THOMAS WOODHAM
. I am a sawyer . On the 30th of July, about eleven o'clock at night, I was in Drury-lane
, with my wife, the prisoner came up, snatched at my seals, the ribbon broke, and he got off with them. I followed, and secured him in Castle-street, without losing sight of him.

ROBERT CRAWLEY
. I am a watchman. I heard the alarm, and saw Woodham stop the prisoner.

WILLIAM READING
. I am a watchman. I assisted in stopping the prisoner, and found the seals on the ring, on him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before H. R. Reynolds, Esq.

1106.
JOHN THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , one handkerchief, value 2 s., the goods of a certain man
unknown, from his person .

HENRY YATES
. I was on duty as a constable in St. James's-street
, and saw the prisoner very active in the mob - he attempted a dozen different peoples' pockets. At last I saw him take a blue handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, and as the Queen left the house, I followed him to Pall-mall, apprehended him, and took six handkerchiefs from him, one of which was that I saw him take I had told the gentleman of it, but he went away.

EDWARD RHIND
. I was with Yates, and saw the prisoner take the blue handkerchief from a gentleman in the square, secured him, and found six handkerchiefs on him.

THOMAS GOOK
. I was in the square, and confirm the witness's statement.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the handkerchiefs of a man on Westminister-bridge.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before H. R. Reynolds, Esq.

1107.
JAMES WATSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , one butt rope, value 14 s. , the goods of
Henry Meux
,
Thomas Stirling Benson
,
Florance Thomas Young
, and
Richard Latham
.

JAMES PEACH
. I am a drayman at the Horse-shoe Brew-house, St. Giles's. On the 6th of September our drays stood by Monmouth-court
. Brooks came to me. I found the prisoner in Bowl-yard, with our butt-rope. My masters' names are,
Henry Meux
,
Thomas Sterling Benson
,
Florance Thomas Young
, and
Richard Latham
.

THOMAS BROOKS
. I saw the prisoner come from the dray with the rope on his shoulder.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 52.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Reynolds.

1108.
BENJAMIN WHITTEY
and
WILLIAM LILLEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July , one coat, value 30 s. , the goods of
Daniel Bristol
.

DANIEL BRISTOL
. On the 4th of July I left my coat in the hall, at No. 19, Holles-street
, at twelve o'clock, at noon, and at six the officer brought it.

JAMES TURNER
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoners going along Gray's Inn-lane with a basket, which had willow shavings on the top, they shifted it from one to the other. I took them into custody. I took the basket from Lilley, and found the coat under the shavings. Whittey ran away. Cadby brought him back.

JOSEPH CADBY
. I was with Turner, followed Whittey, and brought him back.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WHITTEY -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

LILLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1109.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d. of July, one watch, value 3 l.; one seal, value 15 s., and one key, value 1 d., the goods of
Edward Fricker
, from his person .

EDWARD FRICKER
. I am a tailor , and live at Bexley, in Kent. On the 3d of July I was with some friends in Portman-street
at half-past three o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner and several more stood at the curb. I was stopped by the crowd, and turned to go back. Then the prisoner and two or three more, closed upon us, and forced us back into the crowd. I said to my friend,

"Stand back a few minutes, and we shall be able to get back." The prisoner came before us, and in an instant put his hand down. I felt my watch move from the bottom of my fob, and saw him take it out. I immediately seized him, and he gave it to one of the others. They tried to rescue him, but I kept him, and Gall took him.

THOMAS GALL
. I am a constable. The prosecutor gave the prisoner into my charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I was near him, and he collared me. I declare I am innocent.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1110.
ELIZA MOSS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , one trunk, value 6 s. , the goods of
James Wyer
.

GEORGE WELLS
. I am servant to Mr.
James Wyer
, a trunk-maker , who lives in Oxford-street
. On the 24th of July, about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, the trunk was outside of the door. I heard it move; ran to the door; a woman met me, and said the thief had ran down Berwick-street. I followed, and overtook the prisoner at the corner of Noel-street.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A woman asked me to carry it to Compton-street.
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1111.
ROLAND TYLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , one seal, value 7 s. , the goods of
Lambert Gauron
.

JOSEPH BOWDEN
. I am servant to Mr.
Lambert Gauron
, who lives in Drury-lane
. On the 2d of September, about one o'clock, the prisoner and another man came into the shop, he went outside the window, and pointed out two seals, which he wanted to see. I shewed him one, and said it was 5 s. - he returned it. I gave him the other into his hand, and asked 10 s. for it - he told me to brush another seal up. I went to get the leather and brush, and saw him put his hand behind him, and the other man put his hand into the prisoner's hand - he had not delivered me the other seal; my master came into the shop, then the prisoner's companion asked him what a dozen seals would be - he went out immediately - the prisoner then said,

"What can you do these seals at a dozen?" My master told him, and, I believe, he grumbled. I went to get another seal, and recollected what I had seen, and told my master, that he had not returned the seal I shewed him; he stopped the prisoner - he said he had given me the seal, which was false - the officer took him. I should know the other man again. I am sure they were companions.

LAMBERT GAURON
. I came in while the prisoner and another man were in the shop, his companion said he had come about a man who was in trouble, and asked what I could make seals at per dozen? I said 3 l. 16 s.; he said very well, he would call again on Monday, and immediately left the shop. The prisoner looked at a seal, and asked me the lowest price - I said 5 s. I asked the boy to reach a seal from the window, at 10 s. 6 d., he said he had shewn the prisoner that seal, and told me what he had seen. The prisoner said if I would let him go, he would tell me where the man was who had got the seal.

CHRISTOPHER JACKSON
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner in charge. He used great force to get away as I took him to Bow-street, and looked behind, as if he expected a companion.
Prisoner's Defence. The boy has been taken up several times for robbing his master.

LAMBERT GAURAN
. I never charged him with robbing me.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1012.
SAMUEL NICHOLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , one pair of upper leathers, value 2 s. 6 d. , the goods of
John Gibbons
.

JOHN GIBBONS
. I am a shoemaker . The prisoner was my journeyman . I missed a pair of upper leathers, and found them at Wenston's. He said he had them from Robinson, and, in consequence of what Robinson said, I took the prisoner and told him. Robinson said he had the pair of upper leathers from Sadler - he said nothing. Sadler was convicted of receiving them.

ROBERT WENSTON
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Goddard's-rents, Webb-square. Gibbons came to me, and saw a pair of shoes which I was making. I had the upper leathers from Robinson.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a shoemaker. I had the pair of upper leathers from a man named Sadler, who keeps a grinder's shop.

ELIZA KING
. I live in Angel-passage, Long-alley. I saw the prisoner sell the pair of upper leathers to Sadler, and saw Sadler sell them to Robinson.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. They were not his.
GUILTY . Aged 40.

Confined Three Months , and
Whipped .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1013.
HENRY ALLWAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , one gown, value 7 s.; two shifts, value 10 s.; two pair of stockings, value 3 s.; one handkerchief, value 1 s.; one apron, value 1 s., and one frill, value 1 s. , the goods of
Mary Anderson
.

MARY ANDERSON
. I lodged in West-street
. On the 12th of July I went out about eight o'clock at night, and returned at two o'clock in the morning, when I missed these things.

THOMAS CARLOS
. I am a watchman. On the 12th of July, about one o'clock in the morning, I found the prisoner in Greyhound-yard laying down very tipsy, without his hat. His head laid on a bundle containing these things, he afterwards went home with a woman who left him in the dark.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met her in Smithfield very drunk. She took me home with her. She went away and took my hat with her.
- FREEMAN. I found his hat in the prosecutrix's room.

ELIZA GAMBLE
. I live at No. 19, West-street. The prosecutrix is a common prostitute.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1014.
JAMES WADE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of August , two spoons, value 5 s., the goods of
William Sadgrove
, and a watch, value 30 s. , the goods of
Esther Weston
, spinster.

WILLIAM SADGROVE
. I have a warehouse in Moor-fields
. I lost two spoons.

ESTHER WESTON
. I am a servant to Mr. Sadgrove. On the 3d of August the prisoner came to mend a square of glass about eight o'clock in the morning. I missed my watch and two spoons from the kitchen.

THOMAS VANN
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner in his master's parlour. Mr. Sadgrove told him he suspected he had stolen these things. I found the spoons broken up in his waistcoat pocket, and the watch in his breeches pocket.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Whipped and Discharged .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1015.
JOSEPH WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , thirty-nine yards of floor-cloth, value 20 s. , the goods of
James Baber
.

JAMES BABER
. I keep a floor-cloth manufactury , at Knightsbridge
. On the 9th of August, I found the prisoner in custody with this floorcloth, which is mine,

WILLIAM PEARSON
. I am a broker, and live in Old-street. On the 8th of July, between ten and eleven o'clock, the prisoner brought this floorcloth for sale, and asked 6 s. for it-it is worth 21 s., which made me suspect him. I asked him where he got it? he said a man sent him to sell it; I told him to send the man. He left the shop, went a step or two up the road, and loitered about for ten minutes. I kept my eye upon him. He returned and said the man was not at home, and demanded the floorcloth, or if I would buy it, I should have it for 5 s. I detained him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1016.
JOHN THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , one spoon, value 7 s. , the goods of the
Earl of
Morton
.

SECOND COUNT. Stating it to belong to the
Baron
Douglas
.

GEORGE PARKER
. I am butler to the Earl of Morton. On the 29th of August, I was in the pantry, and laid the spoon in the window, which looks into the area. Between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner come down the area, and as he did not ring the bell I went to watch him, and saw him earnestly looking in at the window. Before I got to the hall door, I heard the pantry window open - ran back and saw his hand reaching in and take the spoon; I ran out to seize him - he threw the spoon down under the window and escaped - he had moved it about two feet. I followed him calling Stop thief! he knocked a man down, who tried to stop him. He was secured before I lost sight of him. He dropped it into the sink.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I heard the alarm, and ran to see what it was. I could not overtake him, and was stopped myself. He said I was the man, and had the spoon about me.

GEORGE PARKER
. re-examined. I said so, as I saw it in his hand, and did not find it until I returned.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1017.
THOMAS M'BRIDE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , eight ounces of tea, value 4 s. , the goods of
Anthony Weatherhead
.

WILLIAM COLLIER
. I live with Mr.
Anthony Weatherhead
, who is a grocer , and lives in Coventry-street
. On the 25th of August, about the hour of three in the afternoon, several customers were in the shop; I saw the prisoner come, take a packet of tea, and run out. I followed, and stopped him with it.
Prisoner's Defence. I took it up to smell, and laid it down again.
GUILTY . Aged. 50.
Confined One Year .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1018.
HARRIET MURRAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , one watch, value 3 l.; two seals, value 2 l., and one key, value 15 s. , the goods of
David Harrison
.

DAVID HARRISON
. On the 19th of August, about nine o'clock at night, I met the prisoner in St. James-street, and went with her to the Almonery
. She left me before the morning, and as she had a handkerchief of mine I asked her to return, which she did at five o'clock in the afternoon. I then took out my watch; she said
"What are you afraid of?" I said,
"I am not afraid of you." She took it out of my hand, and went out with it. I slept there three nights, expecting her to return with it, but have never seen it since.

EDWARD HANDLEY
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner about a week before the robbery.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.
FIFTEENTH DAY. FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 29.

1019.
FRANCIS ANDREWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , one coat, value 4 l., and one waistcoat, value 10 s., the goods of
John Banks
, from the person of
William Clutterham
.

WILLIAM CLUTTERHAM
. I am servant to Mr.
John Banks
, a tailor , who lives in Bentinck-street. On the 12th of August, about eight o'clock at night, I was taking this coat and waistcoat to Mr. Winford, Searle's Coffee-house, at the corner of Carey-street; I saw the prisoner and another man; I asked them the way to Searle's Coffee-house, they said lower down. I went on and asked a gentleman who stood at a door. They came up and said they were going there, and would show me. At the corner of Hemlock-court
, the prisoner touched his companion's arm, then snatched my bundle, and ran down the court. I hallooed Stop thief! and the prisoner was taken in three minutes with it.

ANDREW ROGERS
. I live in Hemlock-court. I heard the alarm - the prisoner ran by - I jostled against him, and he dropped the bundle; I picked it up - he was stopped in a moment.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1020.
JOHN PHILLIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , one watch, value 3 l.; one ribbon, value 2 d., and one key, value 10 s., the goods of
James Stone
, from his person .

JAMES STONE
. I am a tailor , and live in Skinner-street. On the 22d of August, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I was in King's-street, St. James-square
- I stood clear of the mob. About ten young men rushed from the crowd, and snatched my watch from my fob; I believe the prisoner to be one of them. I saw it in about ten days, at Bow-street, through an advertizement.

THOMAS CLONEY
. I am a wine-cooper. I was sitting at home at tea, in Great Windmill-street, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, on the 2d of September, I took the prisoner on the charge of Mr. Sawyer. He produced a watch at the watch-house, and offered it to Mr. Sawyer, in place of his own. The prosecutor claimed it.

HENRY MONTAGUE
. I am a footman. On the 2d of September, I assisted in taking the prisoner in St. James-square; on a charge of felony, and saw the watch found upon him.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am a patrol. I took charge of the prisoner at the watch-house. He produced the watch.
(Property produced, and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A person who is gone to sea, pledged it in my name, and I redeemed it; the officer has a memorandum of it.

WILLIAM SMITH
re-examined. No papers relating to it was found upon him. I took him to the pawnbroker's where he said he redeemed it. They indentified him as the man, who pledged and redeemed it.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1121.
SARAH LYON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , ten handkerchiefs, value 10 s.; three silver coins, value 2 s. 6 d., and two copper coins, value 1 d. , the goods of
Samuel Cohen
.
MR. ANDREWS conducted the prosecution.

PRISCILLA COHEN
. I am the wife of
Samuel Cohen
, who is a linen-draper , and lives at No. 168, Shoreditch
. The prisoner was seven weeks in our service. I asked her one day for a scarf of mine, which was washed at home. I had told her to put it under my bed to press - she said she put it under my bed - she seemed flurried, and I went to look and found a parcel containing five handkerchiefs, under her own bed. (the scarf was under mine) I had seen them in the shop the night before. I told her of it, and turned her away. She was apprehended two days after.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How many of your daughters slept with the prisoner - A. One who is about fifteen years old, and a niece seventeen years old. I sent the prisoner away on Friday.

SAMUEL COHEN
. On Friday, while the prisoner was in the house, my wife informed me of this. I told her to keep her till I was at leisure. I then told her that two bundles in the shop had been misplaced and rumpled in the night, and some cambric taken away. The handkerchiefs were mine. She said it was the first thing she ever took. I was called down to the shop. I said she must not go away without being searched. I saw her go out while I was busy. I sent for Levy on Saturday; as my father knew the girl to be a thief, and I missed other things. We found her at her sweetheart's apartments. She was searched and the coins found on her, which I swear to be mine. They were taken from my looking-glass drawer, they were marked in a particular manner by a stamp. It was done some years back. She was then taken into custody, but let go again, as her father said he knew where all the property was. She was apprehended again on Sunday.

Cross-examined. Q. How long were the handkerchiefs missed before you turned her out of doors - A. She was not turned out exactly. My wife said she should not sleep in the house. I had missed nothing but the handkerchiefs when she left. They were worth 3 s. each. I missed no more that day.

Q. Pray, how soon after did you write to Mrs. Gasheer to make you amends for the false character she gave her - A. About three-quarters of an hour, and before I missed any thing else. I said 200 l. or 300 l. would not compensate for what I had lost. I demanded no money of Mrs. Gasheer.

Q. When the coins were found on her, they were in your possession a day and a half afterwards - A. No. I kept them a few hours after, they were found on her on Sunday. I pointed the marks out when they were found, and gave them to the Magistrate on Monday, as the officer would not take them of me.
Q. Did she say your niece took them - A. She said so on Sunday.

MR. ANDREWS. Q. When you missed more property and told her of it, what did she say - A. She mentioned the person who was the instigator of it. Mrs. Gasheer is her aunt. The marks were on the coins before they were lost. Mr. Isaacs, the prisoner's attorney, attended before the Magistrate in my name without my authority.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. At the time Mr. Isaacs attended, was not the prisoner examined as a witness - A. I charged her with the robbery. One Jacobs was charged as the receiver.
COURT. Q. How long before had you marked the money - A. Some years. They were all marked with the same punch. I cannot find the punch now. This is the letter I wrote to Gasheer - (looking at it.)

SAMUEL LEVY
. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner on Sunday the 16th in Roper's-buildings. I had searched her on Saturday at her father's. Her father and Cohen searched her, two shillings, a sixpence, and two halfpence were found on her. I have had them ever since two hours after she was in custody, when Cohen gave them to me - he kept them till then. He had said he would not prosecute her, or I should have taken her on Saturday.
- WARTERS. I produce the handkerchiefs which Cohen gave me at the office on Monday, as Levy had refused to take them, because they had been so long in Cohen's possession.

SAMUEL COHEN
. They are mine.
Prisoner. I leave my defence to my Counsel.
Letter read.

"MR. GASHEER, - This is to inform you that I received a character of a servant from you, whom your wife said had lived two years with you, and that she allowed her to receive money. Now she has robbed me, and you know she has given me a false character. I expect you will make good the property I lost. I shall proceed against you for it, as my solicitor directs.
S. COHEN."

SAMUEL LEVY
re-examined. When the coin was found on the prisoner, I do not recollect Cohen saying he knew them by any mark.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1122.
JESSE BOWTELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , one watch, value 1 l.; one chain, value 10 s.; one seal, value 5 s., and two keys, value 5 s., the goods of
Thomas Ingram
, from his person .

THOMAS INGRAM
. I live in Harley-street. On the 18th of August I was standing at the entrance to Spring Gardens
to see her Majesty pass. A rush came instantly at me. The prisoner came with his arms and held against me with great force. I felt my watch go, and saw the chain hanging from his hand. I seized and kept him till the officer took him. Some gentleman produced my watch.
Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Did not the gentleman say,
"Here is your watch, you have got the wrong man" - A. No. The prisoner dragged me into the middle of the road.

WILLIAM TATE
. I am a tea-dealer, and live in the City-road. I saw the prosecutor rush towards the prisoner, and saw the chain in his hand. I attempted to seize him, but five or six came round, cried Rescue, and threw me into the middle of the road. I saw a gentleman take the watch from the prisoner's hand, and give it to Mr. Ingram.

JAMES HAUDLEY
. I am a constable. Immediately as the Queen's carriage passed I saw a general rush. There was a cry for an officer. I saw two or three gentlemen struggling with the prisoner, and secured him. Several men endeavoured to rescue him. One of the gentlemen who had hold of him gave me the watch. He made great resistance, and it was with difficulty I could secure him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was taken to a public-house. The watch was brought in by a man.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1123.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , one coat, value 1 l. , the goods of
Robert Patterson
, Esq .

ROBERT HUNT
. I was servant to Mr.
Robert Patterson
, who lives in York-place
. I went up to answer a knock at the door; in going down again heard somebody in the passage, and missed the coat from the pantry. The prisoner was brought back with it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN MANDER
. I am a coachman to General Clinton. I stopped the prisoner about twenty yards from the prosecutor's, in the street - a person who was cleaning a window opposite pointed him out to me. He threw the coat down and ran. I followed and secured him.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Confined Six Months , and
Whipped .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1124.
RICHARD BROOKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , one watch, value 5 s.; one shawl, value 10 s., and one scarf, value 14 s. , the goods of
Joseph Gilkes
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1125.
JOHN MANNEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , five pair of shoes, value 30 s. , the goods of
John Chalmers
.

THOMAS DUNKLEY
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Middle-row, Broad-street, On the 25th of July I bought a pair of shoes of one Summer, in Rag Fair, he is not here, and on the 27th I bought three other pairs of him; I also bought another pair of Bumpus, whom I saw buy them of Summer.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I apprehended the prisoner, and found two pair of shoes at his lodgings.

JOHN CHALMERS
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Holborn
, the prisoner was my servant . The two pair of shoes are mine; I do not know when I lost them. I believe the prisoner never bought them. My son has superintended my business for seven years. They are of a particular make, but have no shop-mark on them.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Where were they made - A. At Northampton. The same person makes for other people.
Q. You had notice to produce your books here - A. Yes, but I have not brought them, as they would prove nothing.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1126.
NATHANIEL BRIGGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , one piece of nankeen, value 1 s. , the goods of
William Luke
.

WILLIAM LINDSAY
. I am chief officer of the brig Britannia, the prisoner was a labourer in the East India Docks
, where the brig laid. I thought he appeared bulky, had him searched, and the nankeen was found on him, which had been stolen from the brig-
William Luke
is the owner.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Three Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1127.
WILLIAM M'VILLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , one hat, value 22 s.; one brush, value 9 d., and 17 s. 3 d. in monies numbered , the property of
James Pitt
.

SECOND COUNT, stating it to belong to
William Yate
.

WILLIAM YATES
. I manage the business of Mr.
James Pitt
, who has a hatter's shop in Oxford-street. On the 12th of August the prisoner ordered a hat to be sent to Mr. Bond, No. 12, Colvill-court, Charlotte-street, Rathbone-place - the hat came to 22 s., and a brush to 9 d. I sent them by Wood, and gave him 3 d. for change. He brought them back, and asked for change of a 2 l. note. I gave him 17 s. in addition to the 3 d.; he returned with two 1 l. notes of the Milston-street Bath Bank, made payable at No. 11, Crutched Friars. I sent them for payment two or three days after, he brought them back. I had ordered Wood not to leave the goods without the money. On the 14th I went to Colville-court, and found no Mr. Bond lived there.

Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Q. Did you receive the order from the prisoner - A. Yes, he wrote his name as Bond - he tried three hats on, and said it was for his brother at Romford. I am not in partnership with Mr. Pitt, but merely his agent.

THOMAS WOOD
. I am errand-boy to Mr. Pitt; Yates sent me with a hat and box to Mr. Bond, No. 12, Colville-court - he gave me 3 d., and told me not to leave them without the money. I went to Colville-court, and met the prisoner at the door - I did not knock; I am certain it was him. He said,
"My little man, is that hat for me?" I said,
"Yes, Sir." He asked if I had change for 2 l.? I said I had only 3 d. He said,

"Run back, you may take the hat with you or leave it here; you have no need to be afraid, I will not run away - make haste, as I am in a hurry." I ran back with the hat, got 17 s., and found him at the corner of the court. He said,

"You have made haste, here is 3 d for you." I gave him 17 s. and he gave me two notes - I brought Mr. Yates the same notes, he did not approve of them. I went a day or two after to No. 11, Crutched Friars; I found no such persons as Sampson and Brothers, nor had they lived there for ten years.
Cross-examined. Q. They never sent you to Bath - A. No. There was a man tried at Clerkenwell for an offence at this house.
MR. ANDREWS, on behalf of the prisoner, called

MARY PHILLIMORE
. I live at No. 12, Colville-court. A man about the prisoner's height called about some lodgings, I agreed to take him if his character answered, but he never came again. While he was in my house this lad brought a hat, the man went to the door; Wood had knocked at the door between two and three o'clock, he said he had brought a hat for the man, the man went to the door to him - it was not the prisoner - he was a country-looking man. I left them at the door, and did not see the boy give him the hat.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not see him give him the hatbox - A. Yes, I saw the man with the box when he left me.
Prisoner. I declare my innocence - they both said I was not the man. There is a man now at Sheerness who committed the offence, and has confessed it.

THOMAS WOOD
re-examined. I did not go into the house. I found the prisoner at the door, and am certain I did not knock at the door at all. When I returned with the change he was at the corner of the court. I afterwards took the notes back to get them changed, I knocked at the door then, and Mrs. Phillimore let me in - I had partedwith the hat before this. She said the gentleman only came to take a lodging. I had not been in the house before, but when he ordered the hat he said if he should be out his wife would pay me. When I saw the prisoner at the corner of the court he went to the door, stood with one foot on the step, and paid me. There was another man standing in the court, leaning against a post. I am positive the prisoner is the man - I never doubted it.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1128.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , one shawl, value 15 s., and one watch, value 15 s. , the goods of
John Wright
.

JOHN WRIGHT
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Samuel-street, St. George's in the East
. On the 27th of July, about half-past five o'clock in the morning, I hung this watch by the fire-place and went next door, leaving my door open, but kept my eye on it, and saw the prisoner come along the street smoking his pipe. I came out in a minute and a half, and saw him about twenty yards off; I went in, missed my watch, and saw some tobacco on the boards smoking. I ran out, he saw me, and ran. I called Stop thief! a constable collared him, and I took the watch out of his right-hand pocket - the shawl was found on him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1129.
MARY ANN MATLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , two sheets, value 7 s., the goods of
James Blake
, in a lodging-room .

JAMES BLAKE
. I live in Park-street, Regent's-park
. The prisoner took a furnished lodging of me on the 15th of June, on the 19th of July I missed a pair of sheets, and found them in pawn, she gave me the duplicate.

CHARLES VAUGHAN
. I am a pawnbroker, the prisoner pledged the sheet with me.
Prisoner's Defence. I intended to replace them.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Three Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1130.
MICHAEL KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of August , one snuff-box, value 2 s., and five thimbles, value 3 s. , the goods of
Thomas Potter
.

THOMAS POTTER
. I am a sword-cutler , and live in Vere-street, Clare-market
. On the 23d of August I was at tea in my back-room, and heard a noise at the window, which had been broken, and a plate put against it. I perceived the plate had been knocked down, and a quantity of thimbles gone. Next morning a little boy came to sell me a thimble which I knew to be one of them. He said he lived at No. 9, Steward's-rents, I sent him home. A girl came in and said, a boy was there with a quantity of thimbles. I went there, and found the prisoner laying on the floor on a blanket, and charged him with it. He produced the thimbles and snuff-box.
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Transported Seven Years -
Penitentiary
.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1131.
MARY EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , three pint pots, value 4 s., the goods of
Henry Bell
; two pint pots, value 2 s.; the goods of
Samuel Cordeaux
; and one pint pot, value 1 s. , the goods of
Abraham Redway
.

RICHARD GARDENER
. I keep the Manchester Arms, Adam-street, Manchester-square. On the 9th of August, the prisoner ran into my bar, produced three pint pots, and said,
"Here is three pint pots of yours." My name was not on them, but Mr. Bell's. I asked where she had them, she said
"Baker-street", and ran out. Bell immediately came in, and enquired for her. I pursued, and found her in Portman-square, I found three more pots in her apron.

HENRY BELL
. I keep the Westmoreland Arms . I was in Adam-street, I saw the prisoner pass me, and suspecting her, followed her into Gardener's, she saw me and ran out. We searched her, and found three more pots in her apron.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1132.
JAMES CLUTTERBUCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , one suit of boy's clothes, value 10 s. , the goods of
George Morley
.

JAMES HUNT
. I am servant to
George Morley
, who is a clothes-salesman , and lives in Whitechapel
. On the 18th of August, these clothes hung on the door-post, pinned to a cloth. I heard an alarm, ran out, and a gentleman stopped the prisoner. He immediately dropped the clothes. I saw him running with them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1133.
SUSAN RICHARDSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , one handkerchief, value 3 s., the goods of
Thomas Pizzey
, from his person .

THOMAS PIZZEY
. I am a cabinet-maker , and live in Old Nicholl-street, Bethnal-green. On the 1st of August, about half-past one in the morning, I was in Shoreditch
. I was very tired, and fell asleep on a step. I was quite sober, I was awoke by feeling somebody at my neck, jumped up, and saw the prisoner in the act of putting my neck-handkerchief into her bosom. I seized her, and took it from her. I found my coat-pockets turned out, she cried out Murder! and I was surrounded by about a dozen men, who struck me, and told me to let her go. I held her till the watchman took her. They then made off.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM HUGHES
. I am a watchman. I heard the cryof watch, ran up, and found a dozen or more round the prosecutor, who was holding the prisoner. He gave charge of her, and gave the account he has now.
Prisoner's Defence. He took me home, and gave me the handkerchief instead of money.
PIZZEY. It is false.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1134.
THOMAS SHAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , one watch, value 4 l.; one ribbon, value 6 d.; two rings, value 6 d., and one key, value 6 d., the goods of
Henry Cotton
, from his person .

HENRY COTTON
. I am a cabinet-maker , and live in St. Martin's-street. About five o'clock in the afternoon I was at the end of Waterloo-place
, the Queen was passing. My hands were pinioned down by a gang, who hustled me against the carriage, and I felt my watch go from my fob, About a quarter past six o'clock, I saw them taking a thief to the watch-house. I went in, and enquired for my property, I described it, it was produced to me, and I found the prisoner in custody. I remembered seeing the prisoner near me.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GEORGE DORRELL
. I am a brush-maker, and live in Broad-street, Manchester-square. On the 24th of August, I was in St. James's-square, I saw two suspicious characters leaving the square, and at the bottom of Whitaker-street, the prisoner joined them, and shewed them something. I followed them, met three constables, and pointed them out. The prisoner saw me, immediately ran off, and I followed him into St. Martin's-lane, pushed him into a coffee-shop, and asked what he had in his pocket, as he put his hand in. He said

"Come none of your tricks. I have been robbed of 5 s. 6 d." He had got a watch half out of his pocket, I took it quite out, he said it was his own. I took him to the watch-house. The prosecutor claimed it in the evening.
Prisoner's Defence. The watch was thrown down, a man scrambled with me for it. I intended to give it up.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1135.
BENJAMIN MARSHALL
and
THOMAS CAMPBELL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , one handkerchief, value 2 s., the goods of
George Wentworth
, from his person .

GEORGE WENTWORTH
. I live in Princes-street. I was looking at a print-shop in St. James's-street
, Yates asked me if I had lost my handkerchief. I missed it, and he produced it. He had Marshall in custody.

HENRY YATES
. I am a constable. I had been watching the prisoners for three-quarters of an hour, I saw them go up to Wentworth. Marshall took his handkerchief out, he went round Rider-street. I secured him, and took it out of his hand. About an hour after I took Campbell in St. James's-street.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
MARSHALL'S Defence. He brought the handkerchief up, and said I did it.

MARSHALL -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined Six Months , and
Whipped .

CAMPBELL -
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1136.
CATHERINE MOORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of July , one watch, value 4 l.; one umbrella, value 2 s., and 10 s., in monies numbered, the property of
Hendry Reusch
, from his person .

HENDRY REUSCH. I live in Mercer-street, Long-acre. On the 22d July, about half-past eleven o'clock at night, I went to wash my eye at the pump in Queen-street. I met the prisoner, and treated her with a glass of gin, as she asked me. I went home with her to Charles-street
, she left me in about three hours, we were in the dark. I found my property gone. I informed the watchman next day, and he took her.

PATRICK CRAWLEY
. I am a watchman. I saw Mr. Reusch in the passage of a house in Charles-street. He said he had been robbed, and described the girl; he was sober. I found his umbrella in a room on the first-floor, about four o'clock next morning with the prisoner. She lived on the first floor.

WILLIAM READY
. I am a watchman. I apprehended the prisoner on the second pair front room. The umbrella was not there.

JOSEPH TRIMBY
. I found the umbrella in the room; the prisoner was in bed.
(Umbrella produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. He gave me the umbrella.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined One Year .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1137.
JOHN HALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , one watch, value 2 l., and one seal, value 2 s., the goods of
Hezekiah Shepherd
, from his person .

HEZEKIAH SHEPHERD. I am an assistant at a school . On the 13th of September, about ten o'clock in the morning, I was in the Commercial-road
. A procession was going to her Majesty. I felt my watch drawn from my pocket, and saw the prisoner running two or three yards from me. I followed, called Stop thief! he ran about twenty yards off, without my losing sight of him, - he struggled to get away. The watch was dropped close by where I stopped him.

HENRY WHITE
. I am a ribbon-weaver, and live in Quaker-street. I was in the Commercial-road, and picked the watch up in the kennel, just by the prisoner, and delivered it to the prosecutor.

JOHN STARKEY
. I am an officer. The prosecutor gave the prisoner in charge for stealing his watch, he begged his pardon, and said,
"You have got your watch, let me go."
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I did not take it, others were running as well as me.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1138.
JOSEPH BRYAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , one handkerchief, value 3 s., the goods of a man
unknown, from his person .

JAMES WAYLING
. I am a constable. I was in St. James's-square
, and saw the prisoner in company with a gang of about twenty, going along by the side of the Queen's carriage. I saw him clap his right hand quickly into his bosom. I immediately seized him, and took the handkerchief out of his bosom. Furzeman collared him also, and brought him away.

JOHN FURZEMAN
. I am a constable. I saw twenty or thirty thieves with the prisoner. I saw him follow a gentleman in the crowd, pull his handkerchief out, and put it into his bosom. I lost the gentleman in the crowd, there was so many of them, that it was difficult to get the prisoner out. He said he picked it up; that was impossible, he could not pick it up in the crowd.
Prisoner's Defence. The handkerchief was thrown on my arm, two or three people wished to take it off - I did take it off.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1139.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , one watch value 3 l.; one piece of ribbon, value 2 d., and one key, value 2 d., the goods of
John Napier
, from his person .

JOHN NAPIER
. I live in Grand Junction-street, Whitefriars. On the 22d of August, at half-past four o'clock, I was in St. James's-square
, and felt my watch going from my pocket, a great many people were about. I looked down and saw the prisoner pulling it from my pocket, and saw it in his hand. I seized his hand with it, he stooped down and dropped it. Butcher picked it up. I gave him in charge.

JOHN BUTCHER
. I am a carpenter. I was in the square facing Mr. Napier, and saw him seize the prisoner round the waist. I saw the watch at his heels. I forced myself down and got it.

WILLIAM HURST
. I live in Richards's-buildings, Shirelane. I was with Mr. Napier, he missed his watch, we both seized the prisoner. I saw him drop it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in the square, a parcel of people shoved me into the prosecutor's hands, and said I had robbed him.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1140.
ELIZA WHITTINGHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , one shawl, value 9 s. 6 d. , the goods of
James Perry
.

JANE PERRY
. I am the wife of
James Perry
, we live in Chequer-alley
. About three o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came to speak to me. I missed the shawl immediately she left. She came again in the evening and I detained her.

TIMOTHY PERRY
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Cassels, a pawnbroker, Old-street; the prisoner pledged the shawl with me.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1141.
ISAAC JACOBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , one watch, value 20 s.; one seal, value 6 d., and one key, value 1 d. , the goods of
Thomas Carr
.

THOMAS CARR
. I live in Great York-mews
, the prisoner slept in the harness-room with me. I missed my watch about three o'clock in the morning; he was then gone.

JOHN MARTIN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the 15th of July, he said he took it, and pawned it at Mr. Wise's.

JOHN MARSH TURRELL
. I am servant to Mr. Wise, of Broad-street, the watch was pawned on the 3d of July, I do not know who by.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 41.
Confined Three Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1142.
EDWARD DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , nine pieces of timber, value 5 s. , the goods of
William Woods
.

WILLIAM POWELL
. I am servant to Mr.
William Woods
, a carpenter , who lives at Hampstead. This timber was in a house next to the prisoner's. About ten o'clock at night, I saw him go in with a candle, and bring some wood out. I went in and missed nine peices.

GEORGE FURNAN
. I went to the prisoner's house, and found seven peices of timber.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1143.
JAMES DAVIS
,
JOHN DAVIS
, and
JOSEPH ORANGE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 9 lbs. of ham, value 5 s. , the goods of
Richard Tandy
.

JAMES DURBIN
. I am servant to Mr.
Richard Tandy
, who is a cheesmonger , and lives in Beach-street
. About eight o'clock in the evening, this ham was stolen from the window. Orange was immediately brought in with it.

PETER WELCH
. I am a watchman. On the 28th of August, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was opposite Mr. Tandy's shop. I saw the Davis's about his window; Orange crossed over to them.
James Davis
took the ham and ran down Whitecross-street; Orange followed him. I ran after them - they dropped it, and I secured them, but Davis got away. I took Orange back.

JOHN BROWN. I apprehended James and
John Davis
in bed, about a mile off, in consequence of information which Orange gave. James said, he took it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

JAMES DAVIS
-
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Sent to the Refuge for the Destitute .

JOHN DAVIS
-
NOT GUILTY .

JOHN ORANGE
-
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1144.
JOHN COOK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , one hat, value 2 s.; one coat, value 3 s; one pair of boots, value 7 s., and one pair of pantaloons, value 2 s. , the goods of
David Reece
.

DAVID REECE
. I live in King's-street, Seven Dials
. The prisoner slept with me in the kitchen. On the 7th of September I was ill; I saw him come down stairs, and immediately he left I missed my clothes. He was apprehended about a week after, with the coat and trowsers upon him.

JOHN BARTRAM
. I apprehended the prisoner with the coat and trowsers.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. He lent them to me.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Judgment Respited . - Sent to the Refuge.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1145.
MARY CAMPBELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of August , 14 lbs. of bacon, value 7 s. , the goods of
William Gammage
.

WILLIAM GAMMAGE
. I am a cheesmonger , and live in Great Earl-street, Seven Dials
. On the 2d of August, about eight o'clock in the evening, Sweeney alarmed me; I ran out, and secured the prisoner with the bacon, which she had taken from the window.

DENNIS SWEENY
. I live next door to Mr. Gammage. I saw the prisoner take the bacon, and told him.
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.
SIXTEENTH DAY, SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 30.

1146.
CAROLINE ATKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , one pair of breeches, value 7 s. , the goods of
Thomas Norton
.

ANN NORTON
. My husband,
Thomas Norton
, lives in Windmill-street
. I missed these breeches from the staircase, and found them at the office.

ELIZA INGRAM
. I saw the prisoner going down stairs with the breeches, and stopped her.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1147.
ELIZA MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of June , three pair of trowsers, value 16 s. , the goods of
James Nash
.

JAMES NASH
. I delivered the prisoner fustian to make trowsers with. They were not trowsers.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1148.
WILLIAM PATTERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 30 lbs. of paper, value 10 s. , the goods of the Directors and Guardians of the Poor, of St. Marylebone
.
THREE OTHER COUNTS, stating it to belong to different persons.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN THORP
. I am messenger to the Directors and Guardians of the Poor of St. Marylebone. These papers were deposited in the work-house
, in a loft over the passage. The prisoner was a pauper there.

JOHN MILLER
. I am a cheesmonger, and live in Dorset-street, St. Marylebone. About the begining of July the prisoner brought me these papers to sell in small quantities. He said it was waste paper, which Mr. Watts had flung aside, and bid him take it away.
- WATTS. I am inspector of the poor. I never gave him leave to take them. They were bound, but the bindings are now off.
GUILTY . Aged 76.
Confined Three Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1149.
THOMAS DAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of May
, 140 lbs. of paper, value 50 s. , the goods of the Directors and Guardians of the Poor, of St. Marylebone
; and
WILLIAM CAMPLIN
, was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to be stolen .

JOHN THORP
. Day was also a pauper, and Camplin sold sweetmeats about the street. He was apprehended, and said Day gave it him to sell. Day said it was a bad job, and he was sorry for it.
ELEASER HAMSON. I keep a chandler's shop, in Wellington-street. Camplin has sold me paper, for the last fifteen months. One parcel weighed twenty-five pounds.

RICHARD COATES
. I took Day, and apprehended Camplin at his lodgings, in Park-street. The covers of the books, were found at his house.

THOMAS DAY
-
GUILTY . Aged 59.
Confined One Year .

WILLIAM CAMPLIN
-
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1150.
ISAAC WOLFE
,
SAMUEL WHERRY
, and
DANIEL EDWARDS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , three seals, value 1 l.; part of a chain, value 6 d., and one key, value 2 d., the goods of
John Teasdale
, from his person .

JOHN TEASDALE
. I am clerk to Messrs Crosby and Co. St. John-street. On the 15th of July, between twelve and one o'clock in the day, I was walking along Devonshire-street, Portland-road
; I saw the glass-blowers' procession, and stopped to look at them. A person who is not apprehended, came up and hit me a blow in my neck; I should know him again - I felt it for some moments. At the same time he snatched at my watch; the chainbroke, and he got the seals and key; he then handed it either to Edwards or Wherry, which I cannot say - they were immediately behind him in his company. I seized the man who struck me, and called for assistance. I was beset by several of them, and had stones and other things thrown at me - I still held the man until I was knocked down by several - I saw Wolfe among them. When they had partly dispersed, I got up and found several more hustling me to get my pocket-book. I got away as quick as I could - I was obliged to escape through a gateway into a marble-yard for safety. In an hour or two, I saw Edwards and Wherry among a crowd near White Conduit-house - I pointed them out to Smith; they were then secured. I seized Edwards myself, and gave him to Smith - they both ran away as they saw me with Smith and other officers - they were secured near thirty yards off. When I was in Portland-road, I had a second scuffle with the man I at first seized, and who had been rescued from me. I was struck at several times, and saw Wherry about the crowd. While I was being hustled, I felt a hand in my coat-pocket; as soon as I could turn round, I saw Wolfe was nearest behind me, and several loose papers about his feet, which were taken from my pocket. I was very much beaten. He was apprehended the next day. The second attack was twenty or thirty yards from where the first was.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Whether Wherry or Edwards took the seals from the man, you cannot say - A. No, he extended his hand towards them. They were among the crowd while I was being beat - they threw stones at me; one of the stones hit me in the neck. They were along with the man at the time he robbed me.

JAMES SMITH
. I am keeper of St. Pancras watch-house. I was at White Conduit-house, and saw Mr. Teasdale at the top of the hill; he pointed out Edwards and Wherry among a gang of nine or ten. Edwards turned round and looked, and the whole gang ran off different ways. I followed and secured Edwards - he made great resistance. I told him he was a pickpocket - he then fought very hard, and one of those behind me struck me. As soon as I got hold of him, he whipped his hand into his pocket. I took two seals and a broken ring out of his hand; they have not been owned; he was trying to throw them away. I took him to the watch-house, and the other two were delivered to me.

WILLIAM COLTON
. I am a broker. A gentleman was robbed on the hill near White Conduit-house. While another of the gang was being taken to the watch-house, some persons came up and said they had been robbed. I went to White Conduit-house, and we took fifteen pickpockets.

ANDREW SIRKE
. I am a vellum-binder, and live in Field-lane. I came up the Portland-road directly after Mr. Teasdale was robbed, and followed him down the road to White Conduit-house. I first caught sight of Wherry and Edwards about a quarter of a mile off, in company together with several others. I saw Smith searching Edwards, and assisted in taking some of the gang.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I am a constable. Wherry and Edwards passed me at the corner of Cumming-street, when I was going to Clerkenwell with a prisoner. As I returned I assisted in securing a gang of fifteen, among whom were the prisoners.

JOSEPH CADBY
. I assisted in securing the gang. The prisoners were among them.

JOHN MILLS
. I am a constable. I received the whole gang in custody, and found a small necklace on Wherry.

WILLIAM JORDON
. I assisted in securing the gang; they were being taken into a public-house, a mob of about 150 came round, and threatened to pull the house down.
EDWARDS'S Defence. The seals are mine.

ISAAC WOLFE
-
GUILTY . Aged 15.

SAMUEL WHERRY
-
GUILTY . Aged 16.

DANIEL EDWARDS
-
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1151.
JANE STEWART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , two sheets, value 10 s. , the goods of
Francis Newstead
and
Thomas Jaques
.

FRANCIS NEWSTEAD
. My wife and family keep a laundry
, which the prisoner managed. Two sheets were missed.

HENRY PEACHEY
. I am a pawnbroker. Two sheets were pledged, but the man who received them has left me.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1152.
JOSEPH MALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of June , two pillows, value 10 s., and one blanket, value 5 s. , the goods of
John Powell
.

JOHN POWELL
. I let these things to the prisoner with a lodging.
ACQUITTED .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1153.
EDWARD SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , one pair of trowsers, value 2 s. , the goods of
George White
.

SUSAN LUTWYCH
. I live in John-street, St. George's in the East. On the 26th of July the prisoner came and said Mr. White lent him his trowsers. He went into another room, and put them on.
Prisoner. Q. Was it not usual for us to wear each other's clothes - A. Occasionaly.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1154.
CHARLES SMITH
and
GEORGE MASON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , one watch, value 5 l.; two seals, value 2 s.; one chain, value 2 s., and one ring, value 10 s., the goods of
Robert Chapman
, from his person .

ROBERT CHAPMAN
. I am a cabinet-maker , and live in Ashley-street. On the 28th of August, about four o'clock, I was opposite Carlton-house
; the Queen's carriage was coming by. I stood against the iron-rails, and in half a minute I was surrounded by a gang, and saw my son knocked down. I went to his assistance, and lost my watch. I do not know either of the prisoners.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I am a constable. I saw a mobround the Queen's carriage; the prisoners were among them. There was a general fight between the prosecutor's son and Smith. A person gave Smith to me; I took him to the watch-house, it was said a man in red hair, was in his company. I went directly and saw Mason in Pall Mall, and told him he was wanted; he said he would go with me, and walked by my side to the watch-house.

WILLIAM MASON
. I am a stationer, and live in Chapel-court, Swallow-street. I was with the officer, and saw Chapman by
Carlton House
. About a dozen of the gang got round and hustled him. I did not see the watch taken, but saw it in Smith's hand - he was close enough to take it. A person with red hair was in the crowd; I am not certain whether it was Mason; I had seen them in company before the robbery. I afterwards assisted in taking Smith out of the crowd. I saw Mr. Chapman's son endeavouring to take Mason. I rather think Smith struck him in the mouth. I saw him pass the silver watch to another man.

JOHN CHAPMAN
. I am the prosecutor's son. We drew aside when the carriage came up. My attention was drawn to a man with red hair about a yard off; he could not take the watch. I saw him attempt another person's pocket, and I tried to seize him; he drew me out, I was knocked down and he was rescued. I will not say it was Mason, as I have seen two persons so much like him since. Smith knocked me down while I held the man.

WILLIAM JORDAN
. I saw Smith strike Chapman a violent blow, and I secured him.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1155.
CHARLES MAPP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , one watch, value 2 l., and one key, value 2 d., the goods of
John Carr
, from his person .

ANN BODY
. I live at Camden-row, Bethnal-green-road. On the 19th of August, at four o'clock in the afternoon, I was walking with Mr.
John Carr
on Bethnal-green
, and was met by the prisoner and three more. As the prisoner passed he snatched Mr. Carr's watch from his fob. They all ran off except one, who tried to hinder me from pursuing the prisoner, but I did, and saw him take his hat off. I ran about a hundred yards. He was not out of my sight while I followed. Stevenson pursued the same man and took him. I saw the prisoner full five minutes before he came up, remembered him, and can swear to him. Stevenson and others brought him back in a quarter of an hour. The watch was produced before that. Mr. Carr is eighty-seven years old, his sight is very bad, and he knows nothing about it.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did not you say you knew him by his dress - A. No; I knew him by his features and his person.

CHARLES STEVENSON
. I am a butcher, and live at Bethnal-green. I was in the shop, and heard Body call Stop thief! She was pursuing the prisoner. I ran by her and met a gentleman who said

"There he goes." He had turned round by the Greyhound. I saw him before he turned the corner. He was still running alone. I followed her to Green-street. He turned up North-place. I went a shorter way round, and met him at the end of North-place. He was then walking but very much heated and out of breath. I am sure he is the man. He said,
"Have you got him?" I laid hold of him and said,

"Yes, I have got him now." I did not exactly know what he had been doing, and as nobody came to my assistance I let him go. He turned short round and came back into Green-street as hard as he could. Before he had got to the bottom of North-place a person came up and said he had stolen a watch. I instantly followed him, he crossed Green-street, and I found him in custody in about five minutes. Some brick-makers had detained him till I came. I am certain he is the man. He strongly denied every thing, and said he ran because the people called stop thief. Directly Mrs. Body saw him, she said he was the man, and gave him in charge.

MR.
JAMES CROWDER
. I am an officer in the army. I was passing on the green when I heard the cry of stop thief, and saw Mrs. Body and four young men; one ran off and she pursued him. I followed and saw him take his hat off and wipe his face, and in putting it on again he threw his hand over the fore-court as if he threw something away. I lost sight of him. I went to the spot, and on the railing I found the watch; it had opened in falling. Wild took it up and delivered it to Body.

THOMAS WILD
. I live at Bethnal-green. I picked the watch up under the railings of an empty house.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1156.
MARY JONES
and
JOHN WILLIAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , from the person of
Robert Creighton
, 10 s., and two 1 l. notes, his property .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1157.
ROBERT BREM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , one pair of half-boots, value 3 s. , the goods of
George Turner
.

GEORGE DEAN
. I am foreman to Mr.
George Turner
, who is a shoemaker at Ratcliff-highway
. On the 1st of August I heard a cry of Stop thief, looked out of the second floor window, and saw Jackson following the prisoner. The boots were stolen from the door.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

FRANCIS JACKSON
. I am a beadle. About eight o'clock in the morning I saw the prisoner and others watching different shops. I saw the prisoner take these boots from Turner's shop, and put them under his jacket. I followed and secured him. He threw them down.
Prisoner's Defence. I have neither father nor mother, and do not know where to get bread.
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Transported for Seven Years. -
Penitentiary
.
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1158.
ANTHONY CALLAGHAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , one scarf, value 14 s. , the goods of
Thomas Teasdale
.

THOMAS TEASDALE
. I am a linen-draper , and live at Ratcliff-highway
. On the 9th of August, about half-past seven in the morning, a woman opposite said that a manhas got a scarf from your shop. He had been in the shop just before. The shop was full of people. He passed me going out as she spoke. I looked at him, he walked away about two doors, I touched him on the shoulder and said he had something belonging to me, and asked him to come back - he did so. I put my hand in his outside coat pocket and took out the scarf. He fell on his knees and begged forgiveness.

Prisoner's Defence.
Mary Carey
came to me and put it in my pocket.
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1159.
CATHARINE ARMSTRONG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , one gown, value 7 s. , the goods of
James Hulme
.

THOMAS PERRY
. I am apprentice to Mr.
James Hulme
, a pawnbroker , who lives in Museum-street, Bloomsbury
. On the 26th of July the prisoner came to the shop to pledge two articles, and as she went out she took this gown down, put it under her shawl and went out quickly. I sent the boy after her and followed myself; I saw him stop her and take it from under her shawl.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1160.
ANN BRADSHAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , one set of coral beads, value 5 s., the goods of
William Ramsay
, from the person of
Isaac Ramsay
.

JANE LESLEY
. I live in Pitfield-street, Old-street-road. I was nursing
Isaac Ramsay
, I was in Shoreditch
with him; three women passed me - I turned round, and saw the prisoner take the beads off his neck - I asked her for them, but she ran away. I called Stop thief! and she was stopped.
(Property produced, and sworn to.)

THOMAS HAYCOCK
. I am a constable. I stopped the prisoner, and saw her throw the beads down.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1161.
JAMES JOHNSON
and
WILLIAM JAMES
were indicted for
