stealing, on the 28th of July , one necklace, value 14 s., the goods of
Charles Ray Woods
, from the person of
Charles James Woods
.

HANNAH WOODS
. I am the wife of
Charles Ray Woods
. On the 28th of July I was out with my son
Charles James - Sarah
Wood was carrying him - we were going through Sadler's Wells fields
about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, the prisoners followed us. Johnson came up, and took the child's necklace off, I secured him. He gave his hand a sharp jerk, and I have not seen the necklace since. James ran to the place where he threw it - a gentleman held him while I fetched an officer; another officer secured James Another boy was with them.

THOMAS BURRIDGE
. I am a constable. I saw a crowd, went up, and took James; he said he was with Johnson.

JOHNSON -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

JAMES -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined Three Months , and
Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1162.
HENRY WRIGHT
and
JOHN MATTHEWS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , one handkerchief, value 4 s., the goods of a certain man
unknown, from his person .

WILLIAM BIDGOOD
. I am a carpenter, and live in Castle-street, Oxford-market. On the 16th of July, about nine o'clock at night, I was in the narrow part of Spring-gardens, going into the Park, and saw the prisoners together, feeling several gentlemens' pockets. They followed a gentleman along Cockspur-street, and at the corner of Pall-mall
Wright took up the skirt of his coat, and took a handkerchief out. I went up, told the gentleman, and seized them both. Matthews threw the handkerchief down, and wrested himself from me; I picked it up, called Stop thief! Gillon stopped him in my sight. The gentleman claimed the handkerchief. The gang came round, I told him to follow me to the watch-house, but he did not. I do not know his name.

JOSEPH GILLON
. My father is the watch-house-keeper. I heard Bidgood cry Stop thief! saw Matthews running in the road, and secured him.

JOHN RAYMENT
. I am a smith. I saw Matthews running and seized him - on going up Church-passage he dropped a silk handkerchief.

WRIGHT -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

MATTHEWS -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1163.
EMMA SMITH
and
MARY BYRNE
were indicted for
stealing, from the person of
Henry Fielding Corfe
, two 10 l., one 5 l., and three 1 l. Bank notes, his property .

HENRY FIELDING CORFE
. I keep a school at New Church, Isle of Wight. On the 6th of July I lodged at the Nag's Head, James-street, Covent-garden. About half-past eleven o'clock at night I was going to my lodgings, the prisoners accosted me in Brydges-street, and solicited something to drink. I wished them to pursue a better course, Smith said she should be very happy to do so, but was afraid her friends would not take her back. I walked with them, conversing on that subject, and then went to their lodgings in a court near the Theatre, I might have remained there three or four hours. I sat on the bed, and being particularly tired, I fell asleep - Byrne had left me with Smith. I had taken my coat off, the notes were in the pocket. I awoke about four o'clock, and missed them, Smith was then gone. I got Gooding, and we found the prisoners together in Wych-street - I am certain they are the women - we secured them, and took them to a house. As Gooding was going up stairs with Smith, something fell from her; we called for a light, and found, a half handkerchief lying on the ground, containing my notes; they have my writing on them. We charged her with dropping them; she cried, but said nothing.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. How long did your moral lecture continue - A. I do not know; I merely accompanied her home. I was quite sober. I am a married man.

THOMAS GOODING
. I am an officer. I went with Mr. Corfe, and took the prisoner in Wych-street. I took Smith, and he took Byrne. As I was taking Smith up stairs in a coffee-shop, something fell from her. I found the handkerchief, containing two 10 l., one 5 l., and one 1 l. note, with three half-crowns and one shilling. She said she was sorry for it, and hoped he would forgive her.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .

BYRNE -
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1164.
ALEXANDER READ
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , one watch, value 3 l.; one chain, value 1 l.; two seals, value 1 l., and two keys, value 3 d., the goods of
John Jones
, from his person .

JOHN JONES
. I am a milkman , and live in Tower-street, Westminster-road. On the 31st of August, about half-past eleven o'clock in the morning, I was in Parliament-street
, her Majesty was coming past; I was pressed and pinioned. I put my hands down, missed my watch, and found the prisoner in custody. My watch was produced.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM JONES
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner in company with two others, whom I knew before. I watched them from the corner of Parliament-street, they attempted to take every gentleman's watch who came near them. I saw the other two get on each side of Jones, the prisoner stood in front, and drew his watch out; I seized him and took it from him as he was putting it into his pocket. About forty thieves surrounded us, and if it had not been for the Bow-street officers we could not have kept him. I found a handkerchief on him, which he said was marked, but it was not.

WILLIAM MASON
. I was with Jones, and confirm his statement.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1165.
RACHAEL SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July , one watch, value 4 l.; one seal, value 3 l., and one slide, value 5 s., the goods of
Henry Godwin
, from his person .

HENRY GODWIN
. I am a land-waiter , and live in Mile End-road. On the 6th of July, about ten o'clock at night, I was in Stepney-fields
, the prisoner came up and asked me to accompany her across the fields, as she was fearful - I did so. She said she was a servant out of place, and was going to Southend, but the woman where she lodged would not let her have her clothes as she owed her 2 s. 5 d. I was going to give her 2 s. 6 d., when she asked the time? I said I thought it was a quarter past ten o'clock. She said,

"I must wish you a good night, as I have an appointment at half-past." She immediately ran away, and in about ten minutes I missed my watch. I met a watchman, and told him. I found her at the watch-house with my watch.

ROBERT BLAKE
. I am a watchman. About a quarter before eleven o'clock the prisoner came to me in Fieldgate-street, and said she had a watch, which she meant to pledge - I had known her by her walking the streets. She said she got it out of Stepney-fields. I asked her for it, she gave it to me, and I took her to the watch-house.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The watchman wanted me to sell it to him.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Judgment Respited . - Sent to the Refuge for the Destitute
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1166.
CHARLES SAMUEL SAVORY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , two pair of trowsers, value 35 s., and one handkerchief, value 1 s., the goods of
Charles Read
, from his person .

CHARLES READ
. I am a tailor , and live in Newman-street. On the 9th of August, a little after eleven o'clock at night, I was at the corner of George-street, St. Giles's
, with two pair of trowsers in a bundle. I saw the prisoner and two others at the opposite corner; he crossed directly over to me, snatched the bundle from under my arm, and ran off with it - I followed, calling Stop thief! His companions crosed between us to hinder me, but I kept my eye on him - he ran away with a number of them. I was afraid to go in after him - he was stopped in a minute. My bundle was conveyed away. I am positive he is the man, for I did not lose sight of him.

LEWIS ROBERTS
. I am a watchman. I heard the cry, saw a crowd running, and went in a direction to meet them, the prisoner was the foremost; I laid hold of him, Read appeared immediately, and said he was the man.
Prisoner's Defence. If he saw me take it he can say what I did with it.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1167.
JANE MATTHEWS
and
SARAH RICHARDS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 24 pieces of velveteen, value 20 s., and 30 buttons, value 9 d., the goods of
Daniel Courtney
, from the person of
Sarah Walton
.

SECOND COUNT, stating them to be the property of
Thomas Pearson
.

ANN PEARSON
. I live in Underwood-street, Mile End. I sent
Sarah Walton
with a bag to fetch these things from Courtney's, about two o'clock; she returned about three, with the bag empty.

SARAH WALTON
. I am nine years old. Mrs. Courtney gave me this work in a bag, it was velveteen for breeches. As I came across the fields the prisoners followed me; Matthews knocked it out of my hand, and both ran away. I ran and screamed, and a man stopped Matthews, Richards got away, but was taken that night - I am sure of them both.

MARIA COURTNEY
. I am the wife of Daniel Courtney, who is a tailor. I gave this child the materials for two pair of breeches, she put them in a canvas bag, and left about three o'clock - she went across the fields. I live inStoray-street. I found the prisoners in custody, with the property.

CHARLES EARL
. I am a smith. I was in the fields, and saw the prisoners about two hundred yards from the child. One said to the other,

"Come, or we shall be too late." They went up to the child, Richards pushed her off the bank, and Matthews took the bundle. The child scrambled out of the ditch and ran after them screaming. I stopped Matthews with the property.

JOHN DOWNES
. I am a constable. I took Matthews in charge. She told me where to find Richards, and I took her in about an hour.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
MATTHEWS'S Defence. Richards had nothing to do with it.

MATTHEWS -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

RICHARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Judgment Respited . - Sent to the Refuge.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1168.
JOHN TIMMONS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , one saddle, value 15 s., and one bridle, value 2 s. 6 d. , the goods of
James Tisdale
.

JOHN TISDALE
. I live with
James Tisdale
in Parker-street
. On the 7th of July, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I met the prisoner by the stable with the saddle, and claimed it; he said
"D - n you, take it." I let him go, then called Stop thief! and he was stopped.

JOHN HAYWOOD
. On the 7th of July the prisoner brought me the bridle for sale.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I saw the bridle in the stable, and afterwards went and got the saddle.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Publicly Whipped and Discharged .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1169.
MARY ANN WHITING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , one shirt, value 4 s., and one pair of stockings, value 1 s. , the goods of
Joseph Harris
.

JANE HARRIS
. I am the wife of
Joseph Harris
, we live in Whitecross-place, Moorfields
; the prisoner was a servant out of place , I took her in out of charity. On the 11th of July I missed these things, and found the shirt in pledge.

SAMUEL SANDERS
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner, and found the stockings in her box.

WILLIAM ADAMS
. I live with Mr. Solomon, a pawnbroker. On the 10th of July the prisoner predged the shirt.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I meant to redeem them.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined Three Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1170.
GEORGE CECIL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , one handkerchief, value 4 s., and four bobbins of silk, value 30 s. , the goods of
William Cherry
.

WILLIAM CHERRY
. I live in Turvill-street, Bethnal-green
. On the 27th of July, about eight o'clock in the morning, I went down to breakfast, leaving the prisoner, who was my errand-boy , up stairs, when I returned he was gone - I missed the bobbins and handkerchief. I found him in Shoreditch about five o'clock; he said he took the handkerchief to fetch some silk - I had not sent him.

THOMAS AMERY
. I am a loom-broker. I took the prisoner, and charged him with stealing the silk.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Judgment Respited . - Sent to the Refuge.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1171.
ELIZABETH M'KENZIE
and
MARY WILLIAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , at St. James, Clerkenwell, twenty-three yards of lace, value 1 l. 3 s., the goods of
James Sawyer
, privately in his shop .

EDWARD MILLARD
. I am shopman to Mr.
James Sawyer
, who is a haberdasher , and lives in Goswell-street-road, in the parish of St. James's, Clerkenwell
. On the 11th of July, between two and three o'clock in the afternoon, M'Kenzie came into the shop. Another customer was there. Only myself was serving. The other customer left the shop almost immediately, and another came in. M'Kenzie asked to see some common lace; I handed her some; none suited her; I shewed her several cards. The other customer being in a hurry, I reached her some satin which was behind me; I turned round to do so - she bought some. I then turned to the prisoner again; she said none of the lace suited her and left the shop; I had observed nothing, and had not seen Williams. About twenty minutes after the officer brought the prisoner in, and enquired if I had lost any lace. From the quantity we have I could not tell. He produced twenty-three yards which I knew by the shop-mark. M'Kenzie had bought none. The lowest value is 11 d. or 1 s. a yard.

THOMAS THOMPSON
. I am a constable. On the 11th of July I was in St. John-street, and saw the prisoners in company about a quarter of a mile from Sawyer's shop. I watched them into five different shops; sometimes one went in, and at others the other. I followed them to Sawyer's. M'Kenzie went in and Williams stood at the corner of the window. I could not see what M'Kenzie was doing. She came out and joined Williams - they walked away. I apprehended them about two hundred yards off, and found the lace in M'Kenzie's apron. Miller claimed it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
WILLIAMS'S Defence. I did not know she had it.

M'KENZIE -
GUILTY . Aged 23.

WILLIAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 30.

"A statute having passed subsequent to the commission of this offence, allowing the benefit of Clergy in these cases, provided the value of property stolen be under 15 l. The Learned Common Sergeant reserved this case for the consideration of the Twelve Judges to determine whether the prisoners are entitled to the benefit of the same."
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.
SEVENTEENTH DAY. MONDAY, OCTOBER 2.

1172.
WILLIAM MAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , one quart pot, value 18 d. , the goods of
John Abbey
.

THOMAS DALE
. I am pot-boy to the Black Cap, public house, Cambden-town. I followed the prisoner, and said I was informed he had some of my master's pots; he said he had not, and begged I would let him go. He gave me one of Mr. Clark's pots, and I took him to Mr. Clark. The officer found a quart pot of Mr. Abbey's on him.

JOHN DAVIS
. I took him in charge, and pulled two pots out of his bosom.

JOHN ABBEY
. I keep the Melville, public-house, in Greek-street
- the pot is mine.
GUILTY . Aged 43.

Confined Nine Months , and
Publicly Whipped .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1173.
PETER WELCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of August , one shirt, value 7 s.; two handkerchiefs, value 1 s., and one apron, value 1 s. , the goods of
Joseph Northern
.

JOSEPH NORTHERN
. I keep the Coach and Horses, at Knightsbridge
. About eleven o'clock the prisoner came in and said he was a tailor, and asked if I could get him work. I sent him to a tailor whom I knew, he returned and said he had engaged him. In about five minutes the servant missed these things from the wash-house. I found them at the tailor's, under the shop-board.
Prisoner's Defence. They were not in my possession; I never saw them.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1174.
JOHN SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July , one handkerchief, value 1 s., the goods of
John Simpson
, from his person .

JOHN SIMPSON
. I am a jeweller , and live in Middle-row, Holborn. On the 4th of July I was in Covent Garden
; a man touched me on the shoulder, and asked if I had lost my handkerchief; I felt and missed it. The prisoner was about one hundred yards off with a companion - we secured him.

WILLIAM COLTON
. I am a broker, and live at Battle-bridge. On the day of the Westminster meeting I was at Covent Garden, and saw the prosecutor standing by a man who was selling a composition, and saw the prisoner with two more try several gentlemens' pockets. I saw him try Simpson's pocket, then go away and bring two more; then saw him take the handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket. I asked him if he had lost anything - he said he had. When they saw me touch the prosecutor, two went one way, and the other another. I seized the prisoner, but did not find the handkerchief.

WILLIAM LEE
. I am a Bow-street patrol. They were given into my charge - the one was discharged.
Prisoner's Defence. My mother left me in the market; the gentleman went by and took me.
GUILTY . Aged 11.

Transported for Seven Years. -
Penitentiary
.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1175.
WILLIAM WELLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 18 lbs. of lead, value 3 s., the goods of
Thomas Wade
, and fixed to a building of his .

CHARLES SPRAGG
. I am agent to Mr.
Thomas Wade
, who has premises in Three-Fox-court, St. Sepulchre's
- he does not live there. On the 10th of July the officer fetched me there; I found part of the lead stripped from the gutter of the roof; it appeared fresh cut; about 3 cwt. was stolen; they produced 18 lbs., which fitted the cart shed.

DANIEL ELLINGHAM
. I am a patrol of St. Sepulchre's. On the 8th of July, about half-past three o'clock in the morning, I apprehended the prisoner in Three-Fox-court, in a ruinous place by the cart-shed - he had a trowel in his hand, and was spreading some dirt. I asked what he was doing, he said nothing, but moved off. I immediately kicked against the dirt, and found the lead secreted under it. I followed and overtook him in Long-lane; he begged to be let go, and said he did it through distress. I found a knife on him, which had marks of lead on it. I fitted it to the roof.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1176.
GEORGE DAVISON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June , one coat, value 30 s. , the goods of
Thomas Sturman
.

THOMAS STURMAN
. I lodged in Bull-head-court, Marylebone
- the prisoner slept in the same room. On the 14th of June I left him in bed, and returned in the afternoon, when I missed my coat, and found it at the pawnbroker's.

JOHN WALES
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner; he implored forgiveness, and said he would make the coat good.

JOHN NEATE
. On the 14th of June the coat was pledged - I do not know by whom.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1177.
JOHN MEAD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of September , nineteen pounds of beef, value 9 s. , the goods of
Thomas Cowell
.

THOMAS COWELL
. I am a butcher , and live in Fullwood's-rents
. On the 18th of September, about nine o'clock at night, I heard an alarm, and missed the beef from the back of my shop, I ran out and overtook the prisoner with it.

GEORGE BEGGARY
. I saw him take the beef out of his apron, he pleaded distress.
Prisoner's Defence. I came from Bristol with only three shillings.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Judgment Respited .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1178.
ELIZA PICKETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , one coat, value 25 s. , the goods of
James Robert Cassell
.

JOHN AARON. I am a servant to Mr.
James Robert Cassell
, a pawnbroker , who lives in Old-street
, I saw the prisoner take this coat down, and put it in her basket. I secured her ten yards off with it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went there to redeem things, somebody must have put it into my basket to injure me.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1179.
JOHN NEVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , one pair of trowsers, value 6 s.; one pair of shoes, value 4 s., and 10 s., in monies numbered, the property of
Benjamin Lyon
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1180.
DANIEL MACK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , one watch, value 3 l.; one seal, value 6 d.; and one chain, value 1 d., the goods of
John Mills
, from his person .

JOHN MILLS
. I live in Cornwell-street, St. George's in the East. On the 16th of August, between five and six o'clock in the evening, I was in Cornwell-street
, returning from a walk, somebody came against me, snatched my watch from my fob, and went off with it. It was produced in three minutes.

TIMOTHY CALLAMAN
. I live in Cow-lane, Shadwell. I was coming out of the Middlesex Society-school, and heard Mills calling Stop thief! my school-fellows and I followed the prisoner who was near Mr. Mills. I saw him throw the watch into a gutter, I picked it up and gave it to Mills.

WILLIAM HENRY HUNT
. I am a constable. I secured the prisoner. Callaman said he was the man who threw the watch away.
(Property produced, and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1181.
CHARLES CALLAGHAN
was indicted for
stealling, on the 4th of September , one watch, value 2 l.; one seal, value 5 s.; one chain, value 5 s., and one key, value 1 s., the goods of
Robert Newby
, from his person .

ROBERT NEWBY
. I am a sawyer , and live in Richmond-place, Old-street. On the 4th of September, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon I was in Ball-yard, Golden-lane
. I went there to call on a mate named Evans, who owed me some money; while I was disputing with him, he knocked me down. I was picked up by several people who stood round, and as they took me up, they took my watch from my fob. A little boy came up and said,

"You have lost your watch; I saw
Jack Harris
take it." He ran away. I have not recovered it.

THOMAS HILL
. I keep a chandler's-shop in Little Arthur-street. I saw a crowd in Ball-yard as I stood at my shop, the prisoner and Harris were there, they ran out of the crowd together, and came up towards me. I knew them both perfectly well. In five or ten minutes, I heard the prosecutor had lost his watch. As they came towards me, opposite the Crown and Sceptre door, I saw Harris give the prisoner something which appeared to be a watch. They were about ten yards from me. I informed the constable.

JOSEPH PRINCE
. I am an officer. I heard of the robbery the same day, and Hill gave me the account he has now. Tweedy and I went to the prisoner's lodgings, he was denied to us, we went up stairs, and found him concealed under the bed clothes, with all his clothes but his coat on, it was in the afternoon. I told him what Hill said, he said he knew nothing of it, he did not take it.

JOHN TWEEDY
. I saw the prisoner and apprehended him. I knew him and Harris before, I have seen them in company.

RICHARD STEVENS
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Ball-yard. I saw Harris very busy in picking the prosecutor up, and saw him draw the watch from his pocket, he would the chain round his fingers, and ran off. My lad ran after him. I have not seen him since, and did not see the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not under the clothes.
GUILTY . Aged. 19.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1182.
JOSEPH BARNETT
,
HENRY BADMAN
, and
EDWARD WILLIAMS
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , one snuff-box, value 20 s., the goods of
William Smith
, from his person .

WILLIAM SMITH
. I keep the Stone Kitchen, public-house in the Tower . On the 11th of September, between four and five o'clock, I was on the Tower-wharf
, there was a rowing-match, which brought a crowd round, and my snuffbox was stolen.

WALTER STONE
. I am a constable of Tower Ward. I was on the wharf between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, and observed Barnet and Williams particularly active in looking at different peoples' pockets. Badman was with him, but I did not observe him do any thing. Just as the boats started there was a sudden rush. I observed four or five bad characters, and told a person to tell me if the prisoners left the crowd. In a few minutes I was informed they had left. I came up with them on the bridge which leads to the lawn. Barnett was nearest to me, I took him, and Lewis took the other two, who were further off. We took them to the Guard-house. Just as we entered I heard something drop, at that time Barnett and I were behind, the others had entered the guard-house. I found the snuff-box laying between Barnett and me, he said
"You know I did not drop it." I took him to the guard-house. Nobody was in custody but the prisoners.

JOHN LEWIS
. I saw Badman and Williams on the wharf for a considerable time. I afterwards had information, and saw the prisoners together. I took Badman and Williams to the guard-house. I was before Stone, and was searching them at the time the snuff-box fell. Stone had not entered with Barnett.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
BARNETT'S Defence. The other prisoners were just before me.

BARNETT -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

WILLIAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Life .

BADMAN -
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1183.
JOHN MYER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , four locks, value 8 s. , the goods of
John Adlington
.

JOHN KIDHAM
. The locks were screwed to the doors of Mr. Adlington's house.
ACQUITTED .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1184.
JAMES JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of September , four sheets, value 14 s. , the goods of
Christopher Bulstrode
.

CHRISTOPHER BULSTRODE
. I keep the Wheatsheaf, public-house, at Paddington
. On the 9th of September the prisoner took a bed, and in the morning about five o'clock, I saw him go down with a bundle. I followed him, and said
"You have robbed me," he said
"Oh, master! I have two sheets round me, one in my hat, and one under my arm." I found them so, they did not belong to the bed he slept in.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined Three Weeks .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1185.
CHARLES JAMES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , three pair of shoes, value 9 s. , the goods of
John Fraser
.

JOHN FRASER
. I am a shoemaker , and live at Ratcliffe Highway
, the prisoner was my errand-boy , I had missed shoes, and told my apprentice to watch him. The officer and I went to his father's house, where he slept, and found two pair of my shoes.

ROBERT BUCK
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Fraser. On the 26th of July, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner take a pair of shoes off the shelf, and put them into the wash-house, under the water-butt, afterwards I found them gone from there.

ROBERT SHARP
. I am a tailor. The prisoner brought a shoe to my house about two o'clock the day he was taken, and said the other was at the binder's. I had ordered him to make me a pair.

FRANCIS JACKSON
. I apprehended the prisoner, and found a shoe on him, and the fellow at Sharp's; he said I should find it there.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. Sharpe asked me to get him a pair, I at first refused, and told him to apply to his brother, who was in the trade.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Confined Six Months and
Whipped .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1186.
MARY HOLLES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , one stove-grate, value 8 s.; one lock, value 2 s.; four brass-handles, value 1 s., and three keys, value 1 s. , the goods of
Colin Forbes
.

SECOND COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Ann Forbes
.

THIRD COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Thomas Leman
,

ANN FORBES
. I live in Devonshire-street, Globe-fields. I do not know whether my husband is living, I have not seen him for fourteen years. I have a house No. 11, Dog-row, Bethnal-green
. On the 31st of August, the prisoner came in company with another man to look at it; he agreed to take it, and if I would wait two hours they would bring me 5 l. as a deposit. This property was all fixed, except the three keys. They did not return - I went next, day all was right then. On Saturday morning, in consequence of information, I went to the house, and missed all the fixtures and three keys.
Thomas Leman
was my trustee for the house.

ELIZA VICKERS
. I am servant to Mrs. Forbes. I shewed the prisoner the house, the things were all safe then and on the next day. On Saturday I missed the keys and fixtures.

WILLIAM WIGGETT
. I am a sail-maker, and live in Dog-row. I was going up Dog-row, between five and six o'clock in the morning, and saw a quantity of people round the door of Forbes's house. I stopped, saw the door open, and in a few minutes the prisoner came out; I caught her in my arms, and held her until the officer came - she struggled to get away. I went into the house, and found the stove unfixed. Twenty-five shillings and four screws were found upon her, but no keys.

CHARLES BOLTON
. I live in Dog-row. I was called up, and took her into custody; I found nobody else there, although the door was shut by a person inside when she came out. I found the stove in the passage, and four screws upon her, three of which fitted a door which had a lock taken off.

Prisoner's Defence. A person left a direction with my sister, for me to go to the house to work. A man brought me in, and told me to clean a room out; as there was no pail there, I went to fetch mine, and was stopped at the door.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1187.
ELIZA JOHNSTONE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , two shoes, value 3 s. , the goods of
William Hayhow
.

WILLIAM HAYHOW
. I am a shoemaker , and live in New-road, St. George's in the East
. On the 25th of August, Hart brought in some odd shoes to sell; I identified two of them to be mine. I have been repeatedly robbed. In consequence of what she said the prisoner was apprehended. She was a stranger.

WILLIAM SUMMERS
. I am a constable. I was sent for, and Hart took me to Martha-street - I found the prisoner there. Hart said she sold her the shoes; the prisoner said a man of her acquaintance borrowed fourpence on them.I took her in charge. The prosecutor produced the fellows.

RACHAEL HART
. I am a clothes-woman, and live in Petticoat-lane. I bought these shoes of the prisoner for 1 s. the same day. She said she lent a man a trifle of money on them. I asked for the fellows, she said he made them as patterns.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I leave it to the mercy of the Court.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Judgment Respited .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1188.
HENRY GREEN
,
DAVID PLUMMER
, and
JOSEPH WATTS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , six blankets, value 15 s., and four curtains, value 10 s., the goods of
William Perkins
; 100 lbs. of lead, and one copper, value 25 s., the goods of
William Crowther
, and fixed to his dwelling-house .

WILLIAM CROWTHER
. The house this property was stolen from is mine. I live in Charles-street; Middlesex Hospital
, next door to it. On Sunday afternoon, the 30th of July, about four o'clock, I observed the lead which covered the back-yard and had been fixed to it, was cut away, and put in the hall of the house; the copper was also unfixed, and put there. The person who inhabited the house had taken the key away. I found some blankets and curtains in the copper; the copper was tied in a blanket. About seven o'clock next morning, I found the prisoners in custody.

WILLIAM PERKINS
. The blankets and curtains in the house are mine. I had lent them to the last tenant.

WILLIAM HOUSE
. I am servant to Mr. Crowther. On Sunday evening he sent me and some more men to watch who would come; we waited in the opposite house. At three o'clock the officers left us, we remained, and at half-past five o'clock three men entered the house. We immediately went to the door, and found Plummer and Watts in the passage removing the copper; Green, who was the third, ran into the parlour and hid behind the door, I secured him; the others were secured. The lead had been cut up, and the mortar of the copper appeared fresh.

JOHN HUNTER
. I am a coach-painter. I was upon the watch, and found the prisoners in the house. I secured Watts in the passage; he begged me not to ill-use him.

JAMES LYON
. I secured Plummer in the passage.

WILLIAM HELY
. I am servant to Mr. Crowther. I saw Green enter the house with a knot under his arm; the other prisoners let him in, they were inside. I informed the witnesses, they went in and secured them. They gave no account how they came there.

ROBERT CONNELLY
. I am a labourer. I saw Green come out of the house with two more, on Sunday morning, at half-past seven o'clock, the day before the robbery.

JOHN JONES
. The prisoners were brought to the watch-house with this property. I found a knife upon Green, and a crow-bar in the copper, which exactly fitted the door where it was forced.
GREEN'S Defence. I met Plummer in Oxford-street. A gentleman sent us to the house to fetch the goods. He went to get some beer, and we were secured in the house.
PLUMMER'S Defence. We met the gentleman, and he sent us to carry the load.

HENRY GREEN
-
GUILTY . Aged 22.

DAVID PLUMMER
-
GUILTY . Aged 30.

JOSEPH WATTS
-
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1189.
ELIZA COOPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , one set of bed-furniture, value 10 s.; one pelisse, value 10 s.; twelve napkins, value 6 s; one table-cloth, value 2 s.; one petticoat, value 2 s.; three frocks, value 3 s., and three bed-gowns, value 3 s. , the goods of
Mary Munday
, widow .

MARY MUNDAY
. I live in Middlesex-place, New-road, Paddington
. The prisoner lodged four months with me. I left her in care of my place on the 19th of May, while I went to mind a gentleman's house. I returned on the 2d of September, and missed these things. I found her out, she said she had sold them at two shops in Field-lane.

WILLIAM THISSLETON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner in charge; she took me to two shops in Field-lane. The people declared before the Magistrate they never saw her before.
GUILTY . Aged 55.
Confined One Year .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1190.
ELIZA CROCKFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , one pair of shoes, value 4 s. , the goods of
John Richards
.

MARGARET RICHARDS
. My husband's name is John; he is a shoemaker , and lives in Golden-lane
. The prisoner used to come backward and forward to our lodger. On the 5th of July I missed a pair of shoes and charged her with it; I asked her if she knew anything of them, as she had passed through the passage? she said No, and left. She came again in about an hour very much intoxicated, and produced the duplicate.

JAMES WHITEHEAD
. I live with Mr. Read, a pawnbroker, in Redcross-street - the prisoner pledged the shoes.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 41.
Confined Three Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1191.
RICHARD CLANSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , three fowls, value 5 s. , the property of
Thomas M'Kenzie, the elder
.

THOMAS M'KENZIE, Jun. I am a son of Thomas M'Kenzie, and live in Richard-street, Limehouse-fields
. On the night of the 4th, or on the morning of the 5th of July, we lost three fowls from the backyard and found them at the watch-house.

JOHN FIELDER
. I am watchman of Limehouse. About a quarter past one o'clock in the morning I saw the prisoner come out of James-street and go into John-street, I stopped him and asked what he had got in his righthand; I found it was three fowls; he said he picked them up coming from Hackney; they were dead but quite warm. I took him to the watch-house, with assistance.
Prisoner's Defence. I stopped late at my club, and picked up three fowls.
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1192.
WILLIAM CURLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , twelve pair of stockings, value 20 s. , the goods of
William Stephens
.

WILLIAM STEPHENS. I am a hosier , and live at Norton-Falgate
. Between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, a neighbour alarmed me, I missed the stockings from the shop door, and in about a quarter of an hour found the prisoner in custody with them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

THOMAS JOHNSON
. I live next door to the prosecutor; I saw a man snatch something from the prosecutor's door, I said
"Halloo!" and he ran away. I believe the prisoner is the man.

THOMAS GORTON
. I am a constable. The prisoner ran by me with something under his jacket; I stopped him and took the stockings from under his jacket.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Confined Six Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1193.
WILLIAM BENWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May , two sheets, value 6 s.; three blankets, value 7 s.; one counterpane, value 2 s.; one bolster, value 3 s.; two pillow-cases, value 1 s.; one looking-glass, value 30 s.; one candlestick, value 1 s., and one decanter, value 1 s., the goods of
Jane Gould
, in a lodging room .

ELIZA GOULD
. I am a daughter of
Jane Gould
, who lives in Belt-street, Ratcliffe
. On the 26th of May I let the prisoner the front parlour furnished - these things were let with it. He left it on the 1st of June without notice; I found all this property gone; I saw no more of him till he was liberated from here last Sessions, and then taken I found duplicates of the things in the bureau.

WILLIAM ANDERTON
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Cannon-street-road. I have a bolster and two pillows pawned on the 27th of May, in the name of
James Barnes
, Morgan-street. I believe it is the prisoner.

THOMAS PIKE
. I took the prisoner into custody on another charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I was distressed, and got Barnes to pawn them.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1194.
JOHN WAGDON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , two blankets, value 2 s., and one jacket, value 1 s., the goods of
John Turvey
, and one boat, value 4 s. , the property of
William Hern
.

JOHN TURVEY
. I am master of the Sisters packet , which laid in the London Docks
. On the 27th of August I had these things in my bed cabin; I left the vessel about six o'clock, and missed these things on my return. I found them at the office.

WILLIAM HERN
. I am servant to Mr.
James Bryant
, a coal merchant; his boat was in my care. On the 27th of August, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I made her fast at St. Catharine stairs. I missed it at ten o'clock.

THOMAS PIERCEY
. I am a Thames police officer. On the 27th of August, between eight and nine o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner going ashore in this boat between Wapping New and Old Stairs. I found two blankets in her stern, and the jacket; he said they were his own, and he belonged to the Sisters hoy.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Judgment Respited .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1195.
ANN SANDERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , one apron, value 18 d., and one thimble, value 1 d., the goods of
Thomas Gardener
; and one apron, value 18 d. , the goods of
Susan Pattendam
.

SUSAN GARDENER
. I am wife of
Thomas Gardener
. The prisoner was apprentice d to me from the Marine Society, and has been two years and a half in my service; I keep a haberdasher's shop. On the 19th of July she ran away; I saw her in the street and had her brought back; I talked to her about robbing me of other things, and said I would forgive her. In the evening I missed these things Pilgrim brought them to my house.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

ELIZA PILGRIM
. My husband is a rag merchant. The prisoner came to my house between seven and eight o'clock in the morning, and left a bundle containing these articles; she said she had left Mrs. Gardener, and I endeavoured to persuade her to return - she said she would not. Soon after Mrs. Gardener came; she saw her and ran away.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1196.
JOHN WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , from the person of
John Dean
, one pocketbook, value 1 s., and one 5 l. Bank note, his property .

JOHN DEAN
. I live in Swallow-street. On the 30th of August, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I was in St. James's square
when the Clerkenwell address was being presented to the Queen. The Queen's carriage came up; there was a very heavy pressure from the crowd; two females were before me, who cried for assistance; while my hands were up endeavouring to protect them, I felt something at my pocket, put my hands down and missed my pocket-book, which was safe a moment before; the prisoner was close to me; I instantly seized him, and said,

"You scoundrel, you have taken my pocket-book!" two men immediately seized him and asked me to let him go, but I held him. I found they were officers and I gave him up to them; one of them immediately pulled my pocket-book from his breeches.

JOHN FURZEMAN
. I am an officer. I was in the square with Wales, seized the prisoner, and took the pocket-book from his breeches,
(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN WALES
. I saw the pocket-book taken from his breeches.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw two men scrambling for it, and picked it up.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1197.
WILLIAM WILLIAMS
and
ANN WILLIAMS
were indicted for that
they, on the 21st of July , in a public street and highway, in and upon
Mary Busby
, wilfully, maliciously, and feloniously did make an assault, with intent to spoil, burn, and deface her garments; and did wilfully, maliciously, and feloniously spoil, burn, and deface one shawl, value 10 s.; one gown, value 10 s.; one petticoat, value 3 s., and one pair of stockings, value 1 s., her property, and part of her garments on her person in wear, to her great damage .

MARY BUSBY
. I live in Herod's-place, Well-street, Well-close-square. On the 21st of July, about half-past eleven o'clock at night, I was coming from a dancing-house next door to Mrs. Williams, in Dock-street
; I had lived with her about four months before; we had quarelled before this happened. As I came out I saw her at her door, but did not see her son; she moved her hands towards me; I did not see anything; nobody but her was near me. I immediately felt a great pain at my ancle like burning; I went home took my stocking off, and found three or four holes burnt in it; my shawl was all over with the same sort of stuff, and had holes in it; my gown was the same, and my petticoat. In the morning I went to Lambeth-street and took out a warrant against her; the other prisoner came to me and said he would serve me ten times worse, and said he was behind her at the time.

FRANCIS FREEMAN
. I am an officer of Lambeth-street. The prosecutrix came to me for a warrant and gave me her clothes, which I produce; the stockings appeared to be burnt with vitriol; all her clothes were burnt. I apprehended Mrs. Williams - she declared her innocence.

ANN WILLIAMS
'S Defence. I was washing very hard all that day, and never saw her. All this is done out of spite; she was a common girl.

SARAH SEABROOK
. I live in Dock-street. Busby complained to me of being hurt, and shewed me her clothes; her ancle was burnt just like a pea; there was a great hole all down her petticoat.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
-
NOT GUILTY .

ANN WILLIAMS
-
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1198.
WILLIAM MARSHALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September
, one pair of boots, value 2 s., and four pair of upper-leathers, value 2 s. , the goods of
William Waters
; and
JOHN BAYLIS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to be stolen .

WILLIAM WATERS
. I am a boot and shoemaker , and live in Whitecross-street
; Marshall was my journeyman . On the 1st of September I missed the boots, I went with Prince to Marshall's lodgings, told him he had been robbing me, and found the boots there. He said he took them off the stand as I sat at work. I went to Baylis's, and found four pair of upper-leathers there.

JOSEPH PRINCE
. I am an officer. I found the boots at the prisoner's lodgings.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

MARSHALL -
GUILTY . Aged 46.

Confined Six Months , and
Whipped .

BAYLIS -
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1199.
DANIEL GILBERT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , one gown, value 8 s. , the goods of
Eliza Parratt
.

ELIZA PARRATT
. I am servant to Mr. Long, who keeps a public-house in Charles-street, Hatton-garden
. On the 2d of September the prisoner came in and asked to go backwards, he was told some one was there. He had half a pint of beer and then went. I saw him come into the kitchen and turn back. I went on the cellar-stairs, saw him go into the kitchen, open the dresser-drawer, and take my gown out - he was stopped in the passage with it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 28.

Confined Three Months , and
Publicly Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1200.
WILLIAM DANGTRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , one spoon, value 3 s.; one pocket-book. value 3 d., and one 1 l. Bank note , the property of
William Buckera
.

WILLIAM BUCKERA
. I am a weaver , and live at Mile End
; the prisoner was my servant , he left on the morning of the 19th of July without notice, and I missed my pocket-book. On the Sunday following I had him apprehended.

JOHN CUSS
, I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pledged the spoon with me for 2 s.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had only 6 s. a week.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1201.
JOHN ANDERSON
,
HENRY BAKER
, and
FRANCIS NEAVES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , one fixture (i.e.) one copper, value 10 s., the goods of
James Wilkinson
, and fixed to a building of his .
MR. WILKINSON not appearing, and none of the witnesses being able to prove the property, the prisoners were ACQUITTED .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1202.
WILLIAM DODD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 30 lbs. of lead, value 5 s. , the goods of
John Emmett
.

JOHN EMMETT
. I am a carpenter , and live at Pentonville.I lost the lend from a building, No. 11, Cloudsley-terrace, Islington
.

WILLIAM EMMETT
. I am the prosecutor's cousin. On Friday morning, the 5th of August, about six o'clock, I saw the lead safe, it laid in the house; when I came from dinner I saw the prisoner and another man walking about thirty yards from the house. I suspected the prisoner, as he appeared bulky. I followed them across the field and they dropped the lead.

WILLIAM BROWN
. I am a plumber. I followed the men, and saw the prisoner throw down two pieces of lead and the other man one. I stopped the prisoner.

STEPHEN STANTON
. I am a labourer. I saw the prisoner on the premises.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I heard the alarm, followed the cry, and was stopped.
GUILTY . Aged 24.

Confined Six Months and
Publicly Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1203.
HARRIET SUMMERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , four gowns, value 10 s.; two shawls, value 6 s.; four pair of stockings, value 1 s., and one bonnet, value 4 s. , the goods of
Susan Burden
.

SUSAN BURDEN
. I live in Phillips's-buildings, Somers'-town
. On the 15th of July the prisoner came to lodge with me - this property was in my drawers; she left next day while I was out - I returned and missed it. She was apprehended, and the things found on her.

ROBERT TEASDALE
. I apprehended the prisoner in an alms-house in Crown-street; she was wearing the prosecutrix's clothes.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Judgment Respited .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1204.
ELIZA STINTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , 12 sieves, value 8 s. , the goods of
Robert Walkington Crump
.

DAVID NEVILL
. I am servant to
Robert Walkington Crump
, who is a sieve-maker , and lives in Brunswick-square
; these sieves were outside the door, I missed them, ran out, and took the prisoner with them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1205.
JAMES MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , seven planes, value 2 l.; one stock, value 1 l., and two saws, value 11 s., the goods of
Thomas Squires
; four planes, value 16 s., and one chisel, value 3 d. , the goods of
William Moore
.

THOMAS SQUIRES
. I am a carpenter . On the 13th of September, during the night, the tools were stolen from my workshop. On the 18th I found the prisoner in a garret in Duck-lane, with one of Moore's chisels in his hand - he said he found it.
(Chisel produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found it.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1206.
WILLIAM MARS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of September , one watch, value 16 s. , the goods of
George Bews
.

GEORGE BEWS
. On the 16th of September, about half-past five o'clock, I left my watch in the ship Augustus
, returned at seven, and missed it - the prisoner belonged to the ship.

THOMAS FARRAR
. I live at Shadwell. On the 16th of September, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, I bought the watch of the prisoner.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. It is a great falsity.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.
EIGHTEENTH DAY, TUESDAY, OCTOBER 3.

1207.
EDWARD BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of May , nine gold rings, value 9 l. , the goods of
John Jones
and
Timothy Jones
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Confined Two Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1208.
DANIEL RYAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , one coat, value 5 l. , the goods of
William Sadler
.

WILLIAM SADLER
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in St. John-street. On the 20th of July my chaise-cart was on Newington-green
; I was absent about ten minutes, and missed the coat.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I am a constable. On the 20th of July, between four and five o'clock, I stopped the prisoner near Ball's Pond, with this coat in his apron - he said it was his father's, and that he lived in Cow-heel-alley, Whitecross-street.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Confined Six Months , and
Publicly Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1209.
ANDREW MANN
,
WILLIAM LEMON
, and
PETER CAREY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , 300 lbs. of lead, value 26 s., the goods of
John Hinton Tritton
, and fixed to his dwelling-house .

SECOND COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Samuel Baxter
, and fixed to a building of his.

WILLIAM ATKINSON
. I am a carpenter. I had the care of Mr.
John Hinton Tritton
's house, No. 46, Mortimer-street, Marylebone
. On the 24th of August, at seven o'clock in the evening, I saw the lead safe. About seven o'clock next morning I found it had been stripped off three dormers and part of the ridge. About three hundred weight had been stolen. Carey worked on the next premises shortly before. Mr. Tritton lived in the house at the time.

JOHN COOPER
. I am a watchman of St. Marylebone. On the 25th of August I was calling one o'clock, andheard a rattle spring - somebody said some men were on the roof of No. 46, stealing lead. I ran down to No. 49, the people opened the door; I went upon the roof, and found Mann there. He said two men had been taking lead, but it was not him, for he came there to sleep.
Cross-examined by MR. HONE. Q. No. 47 is a ruinous house - A. The house next door to the prosecutor's is coming down - the door of it was shut.

THOMAS BOX
. I am a watchman. I heard an alarm that thieves were at No. 46; I called two watchmen, and placed them at the back of the premises; the servants said some men were on the roof. I went into No. 45, and found Lemon on his hands and knees behind the door - he said he came there for lead to support his family. I gave him to a watchman while I searched the house, and found Carey in the chimney. I found the lead laying in the same room - it was fresh cut, and some torn off.

SAMUEL HILL
. I am a constable. The prisoners were brought to the watch-house. The lead weighed 312 lbs. I compared it with the building, and it fitted exactly.
THOMAS READ. I am servant to Mr. Tritton. I went on the roof, and missed the lead. It appeared just taken. I found Mann and Cary in the next house.
LEMON'S Defence. I went there for shelter.
CAREY'S Defence. It rained, and I went for shelter.
MANN'S Defence. Being in debt I slept in old houses, and went to this house.

MANN -
GUILTY . Aged 24.

LEMON -
GUILTY . Aged 27.

CAREY -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1210.
JOHN HALSEY
and
WILLIAM BERRY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , one gown, value 7 s.; two bed-gowns, value 3 s.; one frock, value 3 s.; four pinafores, value 3 s.; five handkerchiefs, value 2 s., and one pair of stockings, value 1 s. , the goods of
Gerrard Rawes
.

MARTHA RAWES
. I am the wife of Gerrard Rawes, and live in Winchester-street, Pentonville
. On the 11th of July, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I missed the things from my front parlour, they were in a bundle. I saw them safe at nine o'clock; there was a fore-court to the house, and I believe the window was open. I found them at Hatton-garden.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I am a constable. On the 11th of July, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I was by Pentonville-chapel, about three hundred yards from Mr. Rawes's, and saw the prisoners together. Berry had a basket with willow-shavings at the top. and Halsey had a bundle of wood in his hand. They passed me, and went down Southampton-street. As they passed me Halsey put the wood in his hat. I got Colton to assist me, we found them at the back of White Conduit-house together. Halsey then had a bundle under his arm, and Berry had the basket. Halsey stopped while Berry went to several gentlemen's houses. We searched them, and found a latchkey on Berry, and a bridle on Halsey. He said he picked it up in the field. The basket contained nothing but shavings in it, when I first saw him the basket was bulky, but when I apprehended him there were only a few shavings. Halsey told the Magistrate he was to have 1 s. to carry the basket to Old-street.

WILLIAM COLTON
. I live at Battle-bridge. Taylor fetched me, we found the prisoners near White Conduit-fields. Halsey had the bundle under his arm, Berry was carrying the basket. He said the things were his own.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
HALSEY'S Defence. I saw a man with large whiskers, he wished me to carry the bundle to Old-street.
BERRY'S Defence. I was selling willow shavings.

HALSEY -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

BERRY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1211.
MARY ANN JARVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of September , one pair of half-boots, value 5 s. 6 d. , the goods of
Augustine Boulland
.

AUGUSTINE BOULLAND. I live in Little Newport-street
; these boots hung on a horse in the shop; the prisoner and another woman came and looked at a pair of boots. They bought nothing. The prisoner got up and said,
"There is Bill outside." Both went out, Swindell followed them.

THOMAS SWINDELL
. I am the prosecutor's servant, I went after the woman, and found them in Mr. Wise's shop, and the boots on the counter. The prisoner said she bought them that morning.

GEORGE SMALLBONE
. I am servant to Mr. Wise, a pawnbroker, in Long-acre, the prisoner offered the boots to pledge for 3 s. - Swindell came in and claimed them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met a man in Whitcombe-street, who gave me the boots to pledge.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1212.
THOMAS DORSET
and
GEORGE BERRY BRYAN
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of September , one scarf, value 2 s., and one shawl, value 2 s. , the goods of
Thomas William Dobby
.

THOMAS WILLIAM DOBBY
. I am a cutler , and live on Great Saffron-hill. I was riding down Ball's Pond-road
in a chaise-cart, with my wife and child, the shawl and scarf hung on the tail of the cart. Ward called out that they were stolen. I turned round, and saw Dorset about twenty yards off attempting to conceal them under his coat. He saw me, and let them fall. Bryan was with him. I picked it up, and they ran across the fields.

MARY WARD
. I live in Lower Queen-street, Islington. I was sitting down in Ball's Pond-road, and saw Bryan give Dorset a parcel, they were just at the prosecutor's cart. I saw them come from the cart-tail, and saw the fringe of the shawl at the time he gave it to the other prisoner. Dorset endeavoured to hide it. I ran and told Mr. Dobby. Dorset then dropped it, and both ran across the fields. I saw them in custody next day; I am sure they are the persons.

THOMAS KINSEY
. I live in Ward's-place, Islington.I saw Bryan tread on the wheel, take the things out of the cart, and give them to Dorset; they ran away, and I saw Dorset drop it; they ran across the fields. Mr. Dobby pursued them, but they got away. I saw them next day at the office, and am sure they are the persons.

JOHN UPTON
. I am an an officer. I took Dorset the same night at Islington, about nine o'clock, and took Bryan next day.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

BRYON -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

DORSET -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined Three Months , and
Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1213.
ELIZA COLLETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , one watch, value 5 l.; one seal, value 14 s., and one key, value 7 s., the goods of
John Dobson
, from his person .

JOHN DOBSON
. I live in St. George's-market. On the 10th of June, about eleven o'clock at night, I met the prisoner in Stratford-place, Oxford-street. I went to a house in George-street, St. Giles's
. About six o'clock in the morning I missed her and my watch. I found the door fastened outside, and could not get out.

ANN COX
. I live in George-street. I let the prisoner and the prosecutor in, he was sober. The prisoner rang the bell, and went to get something to drink. She said she had left her bonnet and stays behind her. I did not see her again till she was apprehended.

ALEXANDER FRASER
. I am a watchman. On the 27th of August, Dobson pointed the prisoner out to me. I secured her, she said she never saw him.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw a woman looking over the partition of the room, but whether she got over and took it I do not know.

ANN COX
re-examined. The partition goes up almost to the cieling. Nobody can get over.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Confined One Year .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1214.
JOHN BRENT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of September , one watch, value 20 s., the goods of
Samuel Duckman
, from his person .

SAMUEL DUCKMAN
. I am a sailor . On the 17th of September, about half-past eight o'clock at night, I was in King David's-lane
, going to a fire there; as I passed over the shafts of the engines, the prisoner and three others stood against the wall - they came behind, pushed me along, and as I turned round, whipped my watch from my fob. The prisoner was nearest to me - he got behind two others. I seized him, and the others ran off.
Cross-examined by MR. LAW. Q. You did not see him take it - A. No, but he was one of them, and he was the nearest to me; the others were not near enough to take it.

JOHN DUNCAN
. I am a headborough. The prosecutor siezed the prisoner, and gave him to me; he said
"I have not got your watch, search me." I saw two others with him.
GUILTY . Aged 21.

Transported for Seven Years. -
Penitentiary
.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1215.
JAMES NICHOLLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , one watch, value 1 l., the goods of
James Painter
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1216.
THOMAS GILMAN
and
JOHN DAVIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of July , one watch, value 15 l.; one chain, value 2 l.; two seals, value 1 l., and two keys, value 7 s., the goods of
James Gunn Harris
, from his person .

JAMES GUNN HARRIS
. I am a traveller , and live in Fenchurch street. On the 2d of July, about half-past twelve o'clock at night, I was in Whitecross-street
. I heard a cry of murder! and found a great crowd collected. A number of people were ill-using the watchman. I knew him, and helped him to secure two people, and take them to the watch-house. I lost my watch in the crowd - I did not perceive it taken from me, it was safe when I entered the crowd - I did not miss it until the witness informed me of it. I am confident that Gilman hustled me twice in the mob. I found him at the watch-house on the Friday night following, and was certain of him the moment his hat was put on.

BENJAMIN WHOWALL
. I work for Mr. Gade , a trunk-maker, in Coleman-street. I saw the prosecutor come into the crowd, and saw the two prisoners come up; I am certain of them, they were about six feet apart. Gilman hallooed out

"Tom" and pointed to Davis, who then nodded to him - Gilman pointed to the prosecutor's watch, his seals hung out. Two women were being taken to the watch-house, and as they were being led through the posts at the corner of Long's-buildings, Gilman said to Davis
"Come on!" Davis followed him; they went up the passage, and got close to Harris; a third person was then with them, Davis was going on the right side, Gilman pushed him, and said
"Go along." He then went to the left of Harris, Gilman was close behind, he pushed Harris behind, and the others pushed him on each side. Gilman put out his hand and took out the watch. He said

"Come on!" All three pushed out of the crowd, and went away. I followed them, as I wished to see where they went to. Davis asked Gilman to go down Chequer-alley, he objected, and they went first up Cowheel-alley. I looked at both full in the face; Gilman turned round, and said

"What are you nosing at." I went up the street, tucked my apron up, went to the watch-house, and told Harris. I described them to the watchman, and on Monday night pointed Davis out at the corner of Chequer-alley; the officer took him. On Wednesday I pointed Gilman out, and he was taken; he had a new hat on then, but when he committed the robbery he had a shabby one. When an old hat was put upon him, Harris swore to his being in the mob.
Prisoner GILMAN. Q. Why not take me at the time - A. I could not take three. I saw nobody to assist me.

JAMES HANLEY
. I am a constable. I went with Harris and Whowall on Monday night. He pointed Davis out, and I took him.
JOSEPH PRINCE. I am an officer. On the 4th of July, Whowall pointed Gilman out. I took him; he made great resistance. I was obliged to handcuff him.
JOHN TWEEDY. I and Prince apprehended Gilman.
Davis's Defence. I am innocent.

THOMAS GILMAN
-
GUILTY . Aged 19.

JOHN DAVIS
-
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1218.
JOHN JULIER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , one watch, value 10 l.; two seals, value 4 l.; two keys, value 1 s.; one ring, value 3 s., and one piece of ribbon, value 1 d., the goods of
Nicholas Dechemant
, from his person .

NICHOLAS DECHEMANT
. I live in Frith-street, Soho. On the 3d of July I was in a pastrycook's-shop in Oxford-street
. The City procession was returning from presenting an address to the Queen. I remained in the shop near the door; some people came up, pushed me, and snatched my watch. I have not recovered it.

WILLIAM MILES
. I am a carpenter. I stopped by the pastrycook's window as the procession passed. The prisoner was running with four or five behind him. He stopped directly he came to the prosecutor, looked round, and they all stopped in the centre of the door, made a rush, and I saw the prisoner snatch the prosecutor's watch. I am certain of his person. I told the prosecutor of it. Jones and I ran, caught the prisoner in a public-house in Oxford-street, and gave him in charge.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Who do you work for - A. Mr. Ward, of Pimlico. I am going to the East Indies. I live at Peckham. I lost sight of him, but I am certain he is the man.
Prisoner's Defence. He said at the office that he never lost sight of me. He said he would transport me to get his expences.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1219.
MARY WEST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , one necklace, value 5 s., the goods of
Philip Hubie
, from the person of
Mary Hubie
.

FRANCES HUBIE
. I am the wife of
Philip Hubie
. I sent Clark out with my daughter, Mary; she had a necklace on, but returned without one. I live in Brick-lane.

ELLEN CLARK
. I took the child out between three and four o'clock; the prisoner and another girl came behind us in Brick-lane
, and then came before us; I am sure of her person; the prisoner then leant over my shoulder; I saw her hand go away from the child's neck, and missed the necklace; I charged her with stealing it; the other girl ran away; a gentleman seized the prisoner.

HENRY EDLIN
. I am a butcher. I heard the girl scream out that the prisoner had took the necklace; I saw the prisoner give something to the other girl, who ran away immediately. I secured West and gave her in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I was on the other side of the way.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1220.
MARIA HARVEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , one purse, value 1 d. and 13 s. in monies numbered, the property of
Peter Croiley
, from his person .

PETER CROILEY
. I am a book-keeper , and live in Duke-street, Portman-square. On the 29th of July, about eleven o'clock at night, I was met in Oxford-street
by a party of Irishmen, and was knocked down; my pockets were rifled of a silk handkerchief and other trifles; I received some severe blows; on recovering myself I found the prisoner by my side, and accompanied her to a house in Orchard-street, up three pair of stairs; I was in the same room with her and another woman; I went there for no improper purpose. I began to suspect all was not right, and pulled my purse out; the prisoner immediately snatched it from me, the candles were put out, and I was told to get down stairs or they would break my neck; I got down with some difficulty, and immediately pointed the house out to the watchman; we went in and I pointed the prisoner out; she was secured, and the purse found in the house, in the room I was robbed in; I described it before I saw it.

THOMAS ALLSOP
. I was constable of the night. I was at the corner of Orchard-street; the prosecutor fetched me; I got two watchmen and found the prisoner and two other women in the three pair room; he pointed the prisoner out, and gave this account. I found the purse under the bed between the sacking and mattress, empty; he described it before he saw it.
(Purse produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw him.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1221.
JOHN FITZGERALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , one handkerchief, value 4 s., the goods of a certain man
unknown, from his person .

CHARLES READ
. I am a constable. On the 5th of August, about half-past eleven o'clock at night, as the people came out of the English Opera-house
, I saw the prisoner, in company with another, try several gentlemen's pockets; they followed two gentlemen; I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from one of their pockets, and put his hand behind to give it to the other; I seized him and took it from his hand; a scuffle ensued but I kept him; the gentleman came to the watch-house, but I do not know where he is, or his name, or where he lives; he is an officer, and was going to France.

THOMAS HUNT
. I was with Read, and saw him take the handkerchief from the prisoner's hand; the gentleman said his name was Prince or Price, I do not know which; he gave no Christian name.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1122.
MARGARET WALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , one watch, value 3 l., and one handkerchief, value 1 s., the goods of
Joseph Drury
, from his person .

JOSEPH DRURY
. I am a copper-plate printer , and live in Whalebone-court, Coleman-street. On the 10th of August,about ten o'clock at night, I met the prisoner, she asked me to go home with her, I said I had no money. She said she could pawn my watch in the morning. I went, she put out the light, took my watch from under my head, and went away. A man and woman came up, and said if I did not leave the house he would give me in charge. I went out, saw her running, and told the watchman, who took her. I was sober.

RICHARD PLUNKET
. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house. I found nothing on her. I think the prosecutor was intoxicated, he had been brought to the watch-house two nights before drunk, and charged me with robbing him of a 1 l. note.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1123.
JOHN DOUGLAS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , two cushions, value 10 s. , the goods of
Robert Silk
.

LAWRENCE BARRY
. I am servant to Mr.
Robert Silk
, a coachmaker in Long-Acre
. I saw the prisoner leave the shop with three cushions under his arm. I followed and secured him with them. He said his master sent him for them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 53.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1124.
EDWARD WELCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of September , one rug, value 5 s. , the goods of
Thomas Davis
.

THOMAS DAVIS
. I am pass-master for the County of Middlesex , and live in Vine-street, Liquorpond-street. In the morning, as the waggon was loading to go to Bristol, my man insisted on searching the prisoner's bag, we were taking him to Bristol. The rug was found in it.

GEORGE BROWN
. I suspected the paupers. I missed a rug, and found it in the prisoner's bag.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A countryman told me to take it.
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

1225.
WILLIAM SPENCER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , one axe, value 6 s. , the goods of
James Payne
.

JAMES PAYNE
. I am a blacksmith , and live at Wilsden
. On the 14th of August I lost two axes from my cupboard. The prisoner worked for me as a carpenter at the time. On the 17th of September I found one of them in Atkins's possession.
Cross-examined by MR. LAW. Q. Can you swear to the axe - A. Yes; I know it by a flaw in the make, and I am certain of it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOSEPH ATKINS
. I am a labourer. I bought the axe of the prisoner. He said his brother sent it him out of the country, but it was too heavy for him. I gave him 3 s. for it.
Cross-examined. Q. How far is the public-house from the prosecutor's - A. About one hundred yards.
Prisoner's Defence. I found it wrapped up in a hay-band, about one hundred and fifty yards from the prosecutor's.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .
Third Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.
